CERT-ASL.description: This program is offered by the Department of Linguistics in partnership with the Division of Continuing Studies. The goal of the Certificate is to develop a conversational level of communicative competence of ASL, and a knowledge, understanding, and appreciation of the culture of the Deaf Community; and thereby to develop an awareness of and sensitivity to linguistic and cultural diversity, leading ultimately to enhanced intercultural communicative and cultural competence.
CERT-ASL.subject: ASL
CERT-ASL.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ASL100A - American Sign Language I (1.5)
      • ASL100B - American Sign Language II (1.5)
      • ASL200A - American Sign Language III (1.5)
      • ASL200B - American Sign Language IV (1.5)
    • Complete 3 of:
      • ASL300A - American Sign Language V (1.5)
      • ASL300B - American Sign Language VI (1.5)
      • LING345 - Sign Language as Language (1.5)
      • LING373 - Second Language Acquisition (1.5)
      • LING397 - Issues in Cross-Cultural Communication (1.5)

MNR-ANTH.description: This program is offered by the Department of Anthropology in the Faculty of Social Sciences. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
MNR-ANTH.subject: ANTH
MNR-ANTH.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of:
    • ANTH100 - Introduction to Anthropology (1.5)

Year 2

  • Complete all of:
    • ANTH200 - Cultural and Social Anthropology (1.5)
    • ANTH240 - Archaeology (1.5)
    • ANTH250 - Biological Anthropology (1.5)

Years 3 and 4

  • Complete 9 units from ANTH 300 - 499
MNR-ANTH.notes:
Program notes

  • Only one Minor may be declared on any degree program.

MNR-APPL.description: This minor is offered by the Department of Educational Psychology and Leadership Studies in the Faculty of Education.

MNR-APPL.requirements:
Foundational concepts

MNR-APPL.notes:
• Only one minor may be declared on any degree program.
  • As per the Department of Psychology, courses required for the Applications of Psychology and Leadership Minor may only be applied as general electives toward a Psychology degree.

MNR-APET.description:
This is an interdisciplinary program that combines course work from more than one discipline. Refer to Interdisciplinary Programs for more information.

The Faculty of Humanities and the Faculty of Human and Social Development jointly offer an interdisciplinary program in Applied Ethics. This program is designed to provide students with the resources needed to deal with a wide range of ethical problems they will encounter in their personal and professional lives. Students may obtain this Minor by completing the requirements specified below. It is designed to supplement any undergraduate degree or any professional degree program. Students wishing to take a Minor in Applied Ethics should contact the Humanities, Social Sciences and Sciences Advising Centre.
MNR-APET.subject: PHIL
MNR-APET.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • PHIL232 - Moral Problems of Contemporary Society (1.5)
      • PHIL337 - Ethics: Theory and Practice (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units of:
      300- and 400-level approved courses listed on the Applied Ethics webpage.
    • Complete 3 units of:
      Approved courses listed on the Applied Ethics webpage.
MNR-APET.notes:
Program notes

  • No more than 6 units from any one academic unit may count toward the Minor.
  • Any course disqualified from the Minor Program by overlap with the requirements of the Honours or Major or General or Option Program may be replaced by another approved course at the same level or higher.
  • Only one Minor may be declared on any degree program.

MNR-AE.description:
This program is offered by the Department of Curriculum and Instruction in the Faculty of Education. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

The Department of Curriculum and Instruction offers a 15.0 unit undergraduate Minor in Art Education. The program focus is to provide students with a background in visual expression, design thinking and creative problem solving. The minor has two tracks:

  • Visual Expression and Inquiry in Education
  • Visual Design and Inquiry in Education

The tracks will not appear on the transcript.

MNR-AE.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of:
      • AE103A - Introduction to Art Education I (1.5)
      • AE103B - Introduction to Art Education II (1.5)

      • AE311 - Design Thinking (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      AHVS 200-400 level
    • Complete 1.5 units from:
      • AE305 - Drawing (1.5)
      • AE306 - Painting (1.5)
      • AE307 - Printmaking (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units from:

      • AE322 - Digital Arts (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units from:

      • AE303B - Intermediate Ceramics Studio Explorations (1.5)
      • AE308 - Sculpture (1.5)
      • AE309 - Introduction to Ceramic Hand Building Techniques (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • AE314 - Introduction to Community Art Education (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of the following
        Visual Expression and Inquiry in Education
      • Complete all of the following
        • Complete 1.5 units from:
          • AE303A - Introduction to Ceramics Wheel and Hand Techniques (1.5)
          • AE303B - Intermediate Ceramics Studio Explorations (1.5)

MNR-ACAN.description: The Faculty of Humanities and the Faculty of Fine Arts jointly offer an interdisciplinary program in the Arts of Canada, intended to give students the opportunity to gain a broad knowledge of Canada’s artistic diversity. This is a General Program leading to the BA degree. See General Program in the Faculty of Humanities. Students may obtain a Minor by completing the requirements for the General Program together with a Major or Honours program or other degree program in another department or faculty.     • AHVS482 - Seminar in Indigenous Arts (1.5 - 3)
    • AHVS484 - Seminar in the Contemporary Arts of the Pacific Northwest (1.5)

Note

  • Students may use AHVS 480 and AHVS 482 depending on the topic and with permission of the Associate Dean of Fine Arts.

English

  • Select from:
    • ENSH376 - Literature in Canada to 1900 (1.5)
    • ENSH395 - Topics in Indigenous Literatures after 1900 (1.5)

Fine Arts

  • Select from:
    • FA360 - Theoretical and Critical Issues in the Arts (1.5 - 3)

French

  • Select from:
    • FRAN410 - Studies in Québec or French-Canadian Literature (1.5)
    • FRAN411 - The French-Canadian Novel from the Origins to the Modern Period (1.5)
    • FRAN412 - History of Québec and Franco-Canadian Literature (1.5)
    • FRAN415 - French-Canadian Poetry (1.5)
    • FRAN417 - Comparative Studies in Contemporary French and English Canadian Literature (1.5)

Theatre

  • Select from:
    • THEA414 - Studies in Canadian Theatre (1.5)

Writing

  • Select from:
    • WRIT330 - Media and Culture (1.5)
MNR-ACAN.notes:
Program notes

  • Although there is no formal language requirement for the Program, students are strongly advised to develop proficiency in French.
  • Only one Minor may be declared on any degree program.

BSC-ASSH.description:
This degree program is offered by the Department of Physics and Astronomy in the Faculty of Science. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

Students should also refer to the Physics and Astronomy Requirements.

BSC-ASSH.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ASTR150 - Concepts in Modern Astronomy (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of the following

        • PHYS120 - Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS130 - Physics II (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS110 - Introductory Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS111 - Introductory Physics II (1.5)
    • Complete all of the following
      • Complete 1 of:
        • MATH100 - Calculus I (1.5)
        • MATH109 - Introduction to Calculus (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • MATH101 - Calculus II (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • CHEM101 - Fundamentals of Chemistry from Atoms to Materials (1.5)
      • CHEM102 - Chemical Reactivity Fundamentals with Environmental Applications (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • CSC110 - Fundamentals of Programming I (1.5)
      • CSC111 - Fundamentals of Programming with Engineering Applications (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units of electives

Year 2

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:

      • ASTR255 - Introduction to Planetary Science (1.5)

      • PHYS216 - Introductory Electricity and Magnetism (1.5)

      • PHYS248 - Computer Assisted Physics (1.5)
    • Complete all of:

      • MATH204 - Calculus IV (1.5)
      • MATH211 - Matrix Algebra I (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of electives

Year 3

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • ASTR329 - Introduction to Observational Astronomy (1.5)
      • Complete 1.5 units from ASTR 300 - 499
    • Complete all of:
      • PHYS317 - Thermodynamics (1.5)
      • PHYS321A - Classical Mechanics I (1.5)
      • PHYS323 - Quantum Mechanics I (1.5)
      • PHYS325 - Optics (1.5)
      • PHYS326 - Electricity and Magnetism (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MATH301 - Complex Variables (1.5)

      • MATH346 - Introduction to Partial Differential Equations (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units from:

        • MATH301 - Complex Variables (1.5)
        • MATH311 - Linear Algebra (1.5)
        • MATH347 - Introduction to Continuous Optimization (1.5)
        • MATH348 - Numerical Methods (1.5)
        • MATH352 - Introduction to Probability (1.5)
        • MATH369 - Differential Geometry in R3 (1.5)
        • MATH377 - Mathematical Modelling (1.5)
        • MATH379 - Nonlinear Dynamical Systems and Chaos (1.5)
        • MATH436 - Calculus on Manifolds (1.5)
        • MATH422 - Combinatorial Mathematics (1.5)
        • MATH492 - Topics in Applied Mathematics (1.5)
        • STAT254 - Probability and Statistics for Engineers (1.5)
        • STAT260 - Introduction to Probability and Statistics I (1.5)
        • STAT350 - Mathematical Statistics I (1.5)

Year 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 4.5 units from ASTR 300 - 499
    • Complete all of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS321B - Classical Mechanics II (1.5)
        • PHYS410 - Topics in Mathematical Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS499 - Honours Thesis (1.5)
      • Complete 1 of:
        • PHYS422 - Electromagnetic Theory (1.5)
        • PHYS423 - Quantum Mechanics II (1.5)
    • Complete 6 units from ASTR or PHYS 300 - 499
    • Complete all of:
      • PHYS460A - Colloquium I (0)
      • PHYS460B - Colloquium II (0)
    • Complete 1.5 units of electives
BSC-ASSH.notes:
Program notes

  • PHYS 210, CSC 349A, MATH 122 are recommended.

MNR-ASTX.notes:
Program notes

  • The 9.0 units numbered 200 or higher cannot also be used to fulfill the requirements of a student's Honours, Major or General program, or Option. Any course disqualified from the Minor Program by such overlap may be replaced by another PHYS or ASTR course at the same level or higher.
  • Students should note that most ASTR courses have PHYS and MATH pre- and co-requisites. Students who believe that they are appropriately prepared for an ASTR course without having completed the listed prerequisites may apply to the department for permission to take it.

Year 1

Year 2

    • Complete all of:

      • CHEM234 - Organic Chemistry with Biological Applications (1.5)
      • CHEM245 - Introduction to Thermodynamics (1.5)
      • CHEM260 - Synthetic Chemistry Laboratory (1.5)
      • MICR200A - Introductory Microbiology I (1.5)
      • MICR200B - Introductory Microbiology II (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • STAT255 - Statistics for Life Sciences I (1.5)
      • STAT260 - Introduction to Probability and Statistics I (1.5)

Years 3 and 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • BCMB301A - Lab Techniques & Projects I (1.5)
      • BCMB301B - Lab Techniques & Projects II (1.5)
      • BIOC300A - General Biochemistry I (1.5)
      • BIOC300B - General Biochemistry II (1.5)
    • Complete 2 of:
      • BIOC401 - Gene Expression in Eukaryotes (1.5)
      • BIOC403 - Biochemistry of Signal Transduction (1.5)
      • BIOC404 - Proteins (1.5)
      • BIOC408 - Epigenetic Regulation of Chromatin (1.5)
      • BIOC409 - Proteomics and Metabolomics (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units from:
      • CHEM337 - Bio-organic Chemistry (1.5)
      • CHEM363 - Organic Chemistry Laboratory (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units from:
      • CHEM318 - Instrumental Techniques of Analysis (1.5)
      • CHEM324 - Transition Metal Chemistry (1.5)
      • CHEM347 - Quantum Chemistry (1.5)
      • CHEM361 - Analytical Chemistry Laboratory (1.5)
      • CHEM362 - Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory (1.5)
      • CHEM364 - Physical Chemistry Laboratory (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MICR302 - Molecular Microbiology (1.5)
      • MICR303 - Immunology (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units from CHEM 400 - 490
    • Complete 6 units of electives
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • CHEM499A - Honours Thesis I (1.5)
        • CHEM499B - Honours Thesis II (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • BCMB499A - Undergraduate Thesis I (1.5)
        • BCMB499B - Undergraduate Thesis II (1.5)
BSC-BCSD.notes:
Program notes

  • Students with Chemistry 11 and Pre-Calculus 12 or equivalents must take CHEM 091 before enrolling in CHEM 101. Students with Chemistry 12 and Pre-Calculus 12 or equivalents should not take CHEM 091.
  • CHEM 231 may be taken in the second term of the first year, and 1.5 units of these electives postponed until a later year.
  • BIOL 225 may be taken in the third year as a corequisite to BIOC 300A and 300B. Alternatively, CHEM 245 may be deferred to the fall term of the third year.
  • A list of CHEM 400-level courses and their offering schedule is available in the Department of Chemistry website.
  • An honours degree will be awarded to students obtaining a graduating GPA of at least 5.5. Students must also achieve a minimum grade of B+ in BCMB 499A and 499B should they choose these courses. If a student fails to meet the standards for the Honours degree, but does meet the Major degree requirements, the departments may recommend the appropriate class of Major degree.

      • BIOC300B - General Biochemistry II (1.5)
    • Complete 2 of:
      • BIOC401 - Gene Expression in Eukaryotes (1.5)

      • BIOC404 - Proteins (1.5)
      • BIOC408 - Epigenetic Regulation of Chromatin (1.5)
      • BIOC409 - Proteomics and Metabolomics (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units from:
      • CHEM337 - Bio-organic Chemistry (1.5)
      • CHEM363 - Organic Chemistry Laboratory (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units from:
      • CHEM318 - Instrumental Techniques of Analysis (1.5)
      • CHEM324 - Transition Metal Chemistry (1.5)
      • CHEM347 - Quantum Chemistry (1.5)

      • CHEM362 - Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory (1.5)
      • CHEM364 - Physical Chemistry Laboratory (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MICR302 - Molecular Microbiology (1.5)
      • MICR303 - Immunology (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units from CHEM 400 - 499
    • Complete 6 units of electives
BSC-BCSC.notes:
Program notes

  • Students with Chemistry 11 and Pre-Calculus 12 or equivalents must take CHEM 091 before enrolling in CHEM 101. Students with Chemistry 12 and Pre-Calculus 12 or equivalents should not take CHEM 091.
  • CHEM 231 may be taken in the second term of the first year, and 1.5 units of these electives postponed until a later year.
  • BIOL 225 may be taken in the third year as a corequisite to BIOC 300A and 300B. Alternatively, CHEM 245 may be deferred to the fall term of the third year.
  • A list of CHEM 400-level courses and their offering schedule is available in the Department of Chemistry website.

BSC-BESC.description: This single degree program is composed of a selected combination of courses from the School of Earth and Ocean Sciences and the Department of Biology. Students complete this program in the Faculty of Science and must consult the Faculty Program Requirements.
BSC-BESC.subject: EOS
BSC-BESC.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • BIOL184 - Evolution and Biodiversity (1.5)
      • BIOL186 - Physiology and Cell Biology (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • CHEM101 - Fundamentals of Chemistry from Atoms to Materials (1.5)
      • CHEM150 - Engineering Chemistry (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • CHEM102 - Chemical Reactivity Fundamentals with Environmental Applications (1.5)
      • EOS110 - Oceans and Atmosphere (1.5)
      • EOS120 - The Dynamic Earth (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • MATH100 - Calculus I (1.5)
      • MATH109 - Introduction to Calculus (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MATH101 - Calculus II (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS102A - General Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS102B - General Physics II (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS110 - Introductory Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS111 - Introductory Physics II (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS120 - Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS130 - Physics II (1.5)

Year 2

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • BIOL215 - Principles of Ecology (1.5)

      • BIOL230 - Principles of Genetics (1.5)
      • CHEM231 - Introduction to Organic Chemistry (1.5)
      • CHEM245 - Introduction to Thermodynamics (1.5)
      • EOS201 - Sedimentary Geology (1.5)
      • EOS205 - Mineralogy (1.5)
      • EOS240 - Geochemistry (1.5)
      • EOS261 - The Climate System (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • MATH202 - Intermediate Calculus for CSC and EOS (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • MATH200 - Calculus III (1.5)
        • MATH204 - Calculus IV (1.5)

Years 3 and 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of:
      • BIOL311 - Biological Oceanography (1.5)
      • EOS311 - Biological Oceanography (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • BIOL330 - Study Design and Data Analysis (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • BIOL355 - Evolution (1.5)
      • BIOL370 - Conservation Biology (1.5)
      • BIOL457 - Paleoecology and Environmental Change (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units from BIOL or MRNE 300 - 499
    • Complete all of:
      • EOS330 - Paleobiology (1.5)
      • EOS335 - Isotopes in Natural Sciences (1.5)
      • EOS325 - Earth System Modelling (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • EOS300 - Earth Science Field School (1.5)
      • EOS401 - Oceanographic Field School (1.5)
      • EOS460 - Earth System Science (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units from EOS 300 - 499
    • Complete 1 of:
      • STAT255 - Statistics for Life Sciences I (1.5)
      • STAT260 - Introduction to Probability and Statistics I (1.5)
    • Complete 12 units of electives

Recommended BIOL upper-level courses

  • Select from:
    • BIOL319 - Marine Ecology (1.5)
    • BIOL321 - Survey of Invertebrates (1.5)
    • BIOL322 - Biology of Marine Invertebrates (1.5)
    • BIOL335 - Ichthyology (1.5)
    • BIOL418 - Forest Ecology (1.5)
    • BIOL435 - Molecular Evolution (1.5)
    • BIOL438 - Nutrient Cycling and Prokaryotes (1.5)
    • BIOL446 - Advanced Aquatic Ecology (1.5)

Recommended EOS upper-level courses

  • Select from:
    • EOS403 - Global Biogeochemical Cycles (1.5)
    • EOS425 - Aqueous Chemistry in the Earth and Ocean (1.5)
    • EOS300 - Earth Science Field School (1.5)
    • EOS312 - Introductory Chemical Oceanography (1.5)
    • EOS313 - Introductory Geological Oceanography (1.5)
    • EOS314 - Descriptive Physical Oceanography (1.5)
    • EOS321 - Earth History (1.5)
    • EOS400 - Advanced Field Geology (1.5)
    • EOS401 - Oceanographic Field School (1.5)
    • EOS423 - Advanced Sedimentology and Stratigraphy (1.5)
    • EOS450 - Quaternary Geology (1.5)
    • EOS460 - Earth System Science (1.5)
BSC-BESC.notes:
• Completion of a field school as an EOS elective is recommended. EOS 300 requires that EOS 202 be taken as an elective. EOS 401 requires two of 312, 313 or (314 or 431) be taken as electives.

BSC-BESD.description: This single degree program is composed of a selected combination of courses from the School of Earth and Ocean Sciences and the Department of Biology. Students complete this program in the Faculty of Science and must consult the Faculty Program Requirements.

BSC-BMSC.description: This is a single degree interdisciplinary program composed of a selected combination of courses from the Department of Mathematics and Statistics and the Department of Biology. Students complete this program in the Faculty of Science and must consult the Faculty Program Requirements.

BSC-BMSC.notes:
Program notes

  • For students who have declared this program, the prerequisites of BIOL 184 for BIOL 215 and BIOL 225 for BIOL 230 may be waived.
  • It is strongly recommended that students interested in this program take STAT 260, 261 rather than STAT 255, 256.
  • BIOC 300A or 300B may be prerequisites for recommended courses.
  • With the permission of M&S department, Math 377 may replace Math 376 as a program requirement.

BSC-BPSC.description:
This single degree program is composed of a selected combination of courses from the Department of Biology and the Department of Psychology. Students may complete this program in either the Faculty of Social Sciences or the Faculty of Science. Those choosing a Social Science degree should consult the Social Sciences Faculty Program Requirements; those choosing a Science degree should must consult the Science Faculty Program Requirements.

These programs are intended for students with interests and career goals in any area of neuroscience, including neuroethology, human biology, medicine, dentistry, or nursing. Students should consult with undergraduate advisers in both departments when planning their course schedules.
BSC-BPSC.subject: PSYC
BSC-BPSC.requirements:
Year 1

    • Complete all of:

    • Complete 3 units of:

specializations.concentrationProgramNotes:
Program notes

  • BIOL 499B credit may be counted toward the Neurobiology Option only if the thesis topic is approved by the department.
  • BIOL 360, PSYC 345A, PSYC 451D are recommended electives for this Option.
specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

The Department of Biology offers an option in Neurobiology. Students have the possibility to declare this option, and must complete the courses noted below within the Bachelor of Science, Combined Biology and Psychology, Major or Honours programs. The chosen option will appear on students' transcripts.
specializations.title: Neurobiology Option

BSC-BPSC.notes:
Program notes

  • Students planning to do an Honours thesis or a graduate degree in Psychology are advised to take PSYC 300A and 300B. Students interested in a graduate degree in Psychology are advised to take PSYC 499 for their Honours thesis and PSYC 400A as an elective.
  • Students planning to undertake graduate studies in biopsychology are advised to acquire experience in a research laboratory through paid volunteer, or Directed Studies positions.

specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

The Department of Biology offers an option in Neurobiology. Students have the possibility to declare this option, and must complete the courses noted below within the Bachelor of Science, Combined Biology and Psychology, Major or Honours programs. The chosen option will appear on students' transcripts.
specializations.title: Neurobiology Option

BSC-BPSD.notes:
Program notes

  • Admission and Graduation Standing requirements for the Honours program are governed by the regulations for the department in which the Honours thesis is taken (Biology or Psychology).
  • Students planning to do an Honours thesis or a graduate degree in Psychology are advised to take PSYC 300A and 300B. Students interested in a graduate degree in Psychology are advised to take PSYC 499 for their Honours thesis and PSYC 400A as an elective.
  • Students planning to undertake graduate studies in biopsychology are advised to acquire experience in a research laboratory through paid volunteer, or Directed Studies positions.

BENG-BME.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering and the Department of Mechanical Engineering. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult the Faculty of Engineering and Computer Science program requirements.

Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:

Year 2

  • Complete all of:

Note

  • CSC 115 may substitute CSC 116 in a term when CSC 116 is not offered. However, CSC 116 is strongly recommended.

Year 3

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • BME320 - Engineering Materials with BME applications (1.5)

    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECE330 - Electronic Circuits I (1.5)
      • ECE365 - Applied Electronics and Electrical Machines (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECE360 - Control Theory and Systems I (1.5)
      • MECH380 - Automatic Control Engineering (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON180 - Introduction to Economics and Financial Project Evaluation (1.5)
      • MECH345 - Mechanics of Fluids (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • STAT254 - Probability and Statistics for Engineers (1.5)
      • STAT260 - Introduction to Probability and Statistics I (1.5)
    • Complete 2 of:

    • Complete 1 of:

      • ECE380 - Electronic Circuits II (1.5)
      • MECH330 - Introduction to Mechanical Vibrations (1.5)
      • MECH360 - Design of Mechanical Elements (1.5)
      • MECH395 - Heat Transfer (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Complementary Studies elective (deals with central issues in humanities or social sciences. Must be approved, prior to registration, by the Faculty of Engineering and Computer Science. Consult the Faculty website for a current list of approved courses)

Note

  • ECE 370 and ECE 380 are not acceptable for students with credit in ECE 365 or ELEC 365.

Year 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • CSC349A - Numerical Analysis (1.5)
      • ENGR297 - Technology and Society (1.5)
      • ENGR446 - Technical Report (1.0)
      • ENGR498 - Engineering Law (1.5)
      • BME499 - Design Project (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units of:
      Technical Design Electives (listed below), or Complete 4.5 units from both lists of Technical Electives (listed below) with at least 1.5 units from Technical Design Electives
    • Complete 3 units of:
      Biomedical Engineering electives (listed below)
    • Complete 3 units of:
      Biological Science electives (listed below)
BENG-BME.notes:
Electrical Systems Minor

An Electrical Systems Minor provides additional electrical engineering knowledge and skills, and is open to BME students. See Minor in Electrical Systems for requirements.

Mechanical Systems Minor

A Mechanical Systems Minor provides additional mechanical engineering knowledge and skills, and is open to BME students. See Minor in Mechanical Systems for requirements.

Business Minor

A Business Minor develops business skills that are frequently required by practicing Engineers. See Business Minor Program for requirements.

MNR-BUSX.description: This program is offered by the Peter B. Gustavson School of Business. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
MNR-BUSX.subject: COM
MNR-BUSX.requirements:
Business Minor core

  • Complete all of the following
    • Earn a minimum grade of C+ in each of the following:
      • COM202 - Financial Accounting I (1.5)
      • COM220 - Organizational Behaviour (1.5)
      • COM240 - Management Finance (1.5)
      • COM250 - Fundamentals of Marketing (1.5)
      • COM317 - Management Accounting I (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units from COM ENT, or IB 300 - 499
MNR-BUSX.notes:
Program notes

  • Required courses at the 200-level or higher in the Business Minor program cannot form part of the requirements towards other programs or options.
  • COM 200-level transfer credit may be accepted in lieu of COM 202, COM 220, COM 240, COM 250, COM 317 toward the Business Minor program upon approval by the Gustavson School of Business.
  • An approved COM 200-level course may be used in lieu of COM 317, without the need to make up an additional 1.5 units of upper-level course work for the minor specifically. This does not waive students out of overall degree requirements regarding upper-level units or UVic residency requirements.
  • The courses taken for the Business Minor (COM 202, COM 220, COM 240, COM 250, COM 317) are part of the admission requirements for the Master of Global Business (MGB) and Master in Management (MM) programs at the Gustavson School of Business.
  • Students interested in the MGB program should be advised to take IB 301 as their upper-level commerce elective for the Business Minor.

DIPL-CSIS.description: This is an interdisciplinary program that combines course work from more than one discipline. Refer to Interdisciplinary Programs for more information.
DIPL-CSIS.subject: CS
DIPL-CSIS.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:

      • CS200 - Topics in Canadian Studies (1.5)
    • Complete 13.5 units of:
      Approved courses.
DIPL-CSIS.notes:
Program notes

  • Courses may be chosen from appropriate existing credit courses offered at the University of Victoria, and must be approved by the faculty co-ordinator.
  • A maximum of 4.5 units of transfer credit may be used towards the program requirements.
  • The Diploma in Canadian Studies can be taken as a stand-alone credential, or as a concurrent credential with a Certificate or Degree program.

BSC-MSSH.notes:
Program notes

  • Students with Chemistry 11 and Pre-Calculus 12 or equivalents must take CHEM 091 before enrolling in CHEM 102. Students with Chemistry 12 and Pre-Calculus 12 or equivalents should not take CHEM 091.
  • Most medical schools require two first-year English courses; students are encouraged to take a second English course at some point in their degree.
  • Students interested in pursuing the co-op option are encouraged to take CHEM 212, and to do so prior to their first work term. This course may also be useful for identifying job opportunities after graduation.
  • Some courses will require prerequisites other than those listed as required courses in the Chemistry for Medical Sciences program. Students are advised to check prerequisite requirements well in advance of the year in which they plan to take these courses.
  • In any given year, some courses may not be offered, or may be restricted to students in a specialized program of study. In this event, other equivalent courses may be substituted, with the permission of the Chemistry Department.
  • BIOC 299 and one of either BIOL 360 or BIOL 361 in lieu of BIOC 300A and BIOC 300B may be acceptable. In this case, students will be required to take an additional 300- or 400-level course from one of the courses in the ANTH 352...STAT 355 list to ensure that there are 15 units of required upper-level courses in the program. Students planning on this option must consult with the Program Adviser.
  • A total of 21 units of 300- and 400-level courses are required for graduation.

BSC-MSSM.notes:
Program notes

  • Students with Chemistry 11 and Pre-Calculus 12 or equivalents must take CHEM 091 before enrolling in CHEM 102. Students with Chemistry 12 and Pre-Calculus 12 or equivalents should not take CHEM 091.
  • Most medical schools require two first-year English courses; students are encouraged to take a second English course at some point in their degree.
  • Students interested in pursuing the co-op option are encouraged to take CHEM 212, and to do so prior to their first work term. This course may also be useful for identifying job opportunities after graduation.
  • Some courses will require prerequisites other than those listed as required courses in the Chemistry for Medical Sciences program. Students are advised to check prerequisite requirements well in advance of the year in which they plan to take these courses.
  • In any given year, some courses may not be offered, or may be restricted to students in a specialized program of study. In this event, other equivalent courses may be substituted, with the permission of the Chemistry Department.
  • BIOC 299 and one of either BIOL 360 or BIOL 361 in lieu of BIOC 300A and BIOC 300B may be acceptable. In this case, students will be required to take an additional 300- or 400-level course from one of the courses in the ANTH 352...STAT 355 list to ensure that there are 15 units of required upper-level courses in the program. BCYC-CYC.notes:
Specialization streams

The School of Child and Youth Care offers three specialization streams that students may choose as part of their degree.

A student may satisfy the requirements for up to two specialization streams by completing the necessary coursework and a CYC 410 or CYC 411 practicum in a setting relevant for both specialization streams.

MNR-CHIN.notes:
Program notes

  • Students may use PAAS 395, PAAS 494, PAAS 497 towards the 9 units of 300- and 400-level PAAS coursework depending on the topic and with permission of the undergraduate adviser.
  • First-language Speakers of Chinese may use PAAS 494, PAAS 495, PAAS 496, PAAS 497 towards the 6 units of language requirement depending on the topic and with permission of the undergraduate adviser.
  • PAAS 318, PAAS 410, PAAS 411, PAAS 412, PAAS 413, PAAS 418, PAAS 420, PAAS 452, PAAS 457, PAAS 458, PAAS 459, PAAS 494, PAAS 497 may not be counted towards both the required 9 units of 300- and 400-level PAAS coursework and the language requirement.
  • Only one Minor may be declared on any degree program.

MNR-CSS.description: This program is offered by the Department of Geography in the Faculty of Social Sciences. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
MNR-CSS.subject: GEOG
MNR-CSS.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:

    • Complete 1 of:

Year 2

  • Complete all of:
    • GEOG252 - Introduction to Coastal Geography (1.5)

Years 3 and 4

  • Complete 6 of:

MNR-CSS.notes:
Program notes

  • Students interested in a more science-oriented program are particularly encouraged to take GEOG 103, 222, 226, 228 and 274.
  • Students may substitute two of the following courses for two of the GEOG 303 to 474 list: ANTH 449, BIOL 311, 319, 322, ECON 382, EOS 350, 408, 431, ES 446, ER 335B.
  • Students cannot combine a General program in Coastal Studies with a General program in Geography.
  • Only one Minor may be declared on any degree program.

PSC-COMG.description: This program is offered by the Department of Art History and Visual Studies in the Faculty of Fine Arts in partnership with the Division of Continuing Studies. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
PSC-COMG.subject: AHVS
PSC-COMG.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • AHVS488B - Collections Management (1.5)
      • AHVS488D - Caring for Museum Collections (1.5)
      • AHVS488X - Curatorial Planning and Practice (1.5)
    • Complete all of the following
      • Complete 1.5 units from:
        • AHVS488A - Managing Cultural Organizations (1.5)
        • AHVS488C - Communicating Through Exhibitions (1.5)
        • AHVS488G - Public Programming (1.5)
        • AHVS488H - Topics in Museum Studies (0.5 - 1.5)
        • AHVS488I - Indigenous Cultural Stewardship (1.5)
        • AHVS488J - Contemporary Perspectives in Curatorship (1.5)
        • AHVS488K - Exhibition Planning and Design (1.5)
        • AHVS488N - Digital Planning for the Cultural Sector (1.5)
        • AHVS488S - Building Community Relationships (1.5)
        • AHVS488U - Managing Archival Collections (1.5)
        • AHVS488V - Museums as Learning Environments (1.5)
        • AHVS488W - Community Engagement and Social Change (1.5)
        • AHVS488Y - Visitor Experiences (1.5)
      • selected in consultation with the Cultural Resource Management Program
PSC-COMG.notes:
Program notes

  • Students who complete a Professional Specialization Certificate (PSC) in Collections Management are able to transfer four courses (6.0 units) upon admission to the Diploma in Cultural Resource Management.
  • Courses taken to satisfy the PSC in Collections Management cannot be used to complete requirements for an Honours or Major in Art History and Visual Studies, or a Minor in Museum Studies. However, they can be used to satisfy co- or pre-requisites.
  • Students may register in two credentials concurrently. Courses from the PSC in Collections Management and/or PSC in Visitor and Community Engagement may be laddered into the diploma to a maximum of 10.5 units combined. For laddering to occur, the PSC must be awarded concurrently with or prior to the diploma.
  • Credit for courses applied to a PSC cannot be applied to an additional certificate program.

BCOM.description: This degree program is offered by the Peter B. Gustavson School of Business. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult the School of Business academic regulations.
BCOM.subject: COM
BCOM.requirements:

      • COM361 - International Business (1.5)
      • COM362 - Business and Sustainability (1.5)
      • COM371 - Management Finance (1.5)
      • COM402 - Legal Issues in Management (1.5)
      • COM405 - Career Preparation Across Borders (0)
    • Complete 1 of:

specializations.requirements:
• Complete all of:
    • ENT400 - Strategic Management for the Entrepreneurship Specialist (1.5)
    • ENT410 - Venture Marketing Expertise (Promise Skills) (1.5)
    • ENT411 - Venture Planning/Finance Expertise (Planning Skills) (1.5)
    • ENT412 - Acquiring Expert Venture Cognitions (1.5)
    • ENT413 - Portfolio Practicum (1.5)
specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

Entrepreneurship is a five-course specialization, including ENT 400. Students in the Entrepreneurship specialization complete ENT 400 instead of COM 400.
specializations.title: Entrepreneurship

specializations.requirements:
• Complete all of:
    • IB415 - Cross-National Management (1.5)
    • IB416 - International Marketing (1.5)
    • IB417 - International Finance (1.5)
specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

For students interested in specializing in International Business, 3.0 units of a foreign language, or equivalent competence are strongly recommended within their pre-Commerce course work.

The International Business specialization requires that students have direct international experience outside North America. This requirement may be satisfied by participating in the international exchange program or in an international work study (IB 418) in the Fall term (at an additional cost). The requirement will be waived for international students and those who have completed at least one year of high school or university studies in a country in which English is not the primary language.

International Business is a three-course specialization.
specializations.title: International Business Management

specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

Students may elect not to complete a specialization.

In addition to the 18 units of program core courses, students can select courses of interest from the specialization and open Commerce elective courses to make a total of 12 units (prerequisites/corequisites still apply). Priority registration in specialization courses goes to students in that specialization.
specializations.title: Non-specialized

specializations.requirements:
• Complete all of:
    • SMGT415 - Customer Experience Management (1.5)
    • SMGT416 - Service Operations and Quality Management (1.5)
    • SMGT417 - Service Human Resource Management (1.5)
specializations.description: Service Management is a three-course specialization.
specializations.programRequirements: Program requirements
specializations.title: Service Management

BCOM.notes:
Program notes

  • COM 204 may be completed in Year 2. The BCom program core, consisting of the above-listed 300-level COM courses plus 205, must be taken during the Fall and Spring term of Year 3. COM 400, 402 and 405 are completed during fourth year. COM 400 and 405 should normally be taken in the final academic term. COM 402 can be taken at any point during fourth year, usually in the elective term.
  • Students in the Entrepreneurship specialization complete ENT 400 instead of COM 400.
Specializations

There are three specializations:

  • International Business Management
  • Entrepreneurship
  • Service Management

BENG-CENG.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in the Faculty of Engineering and Computer Science. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BENG-CENG.subject: ECE
BENG-CENG.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:

      • ENGR120 - Design and Communication II (2.5)

    • Complete all of:

    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:

        • PHYS111 - Introductory Physics II (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS122 - Mechanics for Engineers (1.5)

Note

  • Students normally must successfully complete ENGR 130 (Introduction to Professional Practice) before undertaking their first work term.

Year 2

    • CSC116 - Fundamentals of Programming with Engineering Applications II (1.5)

    • ECE220 - Electrical Properties of Materials (1.5)

    • ECE242 - Discrete Structures in Engineering (1.5)
    • ECE250 - Linear Circuits I (1.5)
    • ECE255 - Introduction to Computer Architecture (1.5)
    • ECE260 - Continuous-Time Signals and Systems (1.5)
    • ECE299 - Introduction to Electrical and Computer Engineering Design (1.5)
    • MATH200 - Calculus III (1.5)
    • MATH204 - Calculus IV (1.5)
    • STAT254 - Probability and Statistics for Engineers (1.5)

Note

  • CSC 115 may be substituted in a term when CSC 116 is not offered. CSC 116 is strongly recommended.

Year 3

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ECE300 - Linear Circuits II (1.5)
      • ECE310 - Digital Signal Processing I (1.5)
      • ECE320 - Electronic Devices I (1.5)
      • ECE330 - Electronic Circuits I (1.5)
      • ECE340 - Applied Electromagnetics and Photonics (1.5)
      • ECE355 - Microprocessor-Based Systems (1.5)
      • ECE356 - Engineering System Software (1.5)
      • ECE363 - Communication Networks (1.5)
      • ECE399 - Design Project I (1.5)
    • Complete 2 of:
      • ECE350 - Communications Theory and Systems I (1.5)
      • ECE360 - Control Theory and Systems I (1.5)
      • ECE370 - Electromechanical Energy Conversion (1.5)
      • ECE380 - Electronic Circuits II (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Natural Science Electives. A course in natural science as required by CEAB guidelines and as approved by the Faculty of Engineering and Computer Science. Students may choose a course from a pre-approved list: www.uvic.ca/engineering/ece/current/undergraduate/advising/science-elective/index.php or seek permission from the Engineering Undergraduate Office (EUO).

Year 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • CSC349A - Numerical Analysis (1.5)
      • ECE499 - Design Project II (1.5)
      • ECON180 - Introduction to Economics and Financial Project Evaluation (1.5)
      • ENGR297 - Technology and Society (1.5)
      • ENGR446 - Technical Report (1.0)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Complementary Studies Electives. A course deals with central issues in humanities or social sciences, as required by CEAB guidelines for complementary studies, and as approved by the Faculty of Engineering and Computer Science. Students may choose a course from a pre-approved list www.uvic.ca/engineering/undergraduate/advising/planning/index.php or seek permission from the Engineering Undergraduate Office (EUO).
    • Complete 10.5 units of:
      Technical Electives

Notes

  • ENGR 297 may also be completed in other years.
  • Students normally take ENGR 446 in the term preceding the final term of their academic program (academic or work term.)
  • A list of technical electives, and the terms in which they are normally offered, can be found at: www.uvic.ca/engineering/ece/current/undergraduate/advising/schedule. Not all technical electives will be offered every year. Some electives may be offered in a different term than listed.

    • Complete all of:
      • ECE335 - Biosensors and Instrumentation (1.5)
    • Earned at least 3.0 units from the following as Technical Elective:
      • ECE402 - Biomedical Imaging Modalities (1.5)
      • ECE434 - Biophotonics (1.5)
      • ECE435 - Medical Image Processing (1.5)
      • PHYS432 - Medical Physics (1.5)

Note

  • BIOL 190A or BIOL 186 and BIOL 225 cover prerequisite material necessary for admission to the medical program at UBC. Please refer to the UBC medical program requirements at mdprogram.med.ubc.ca/admissions/admission-requirements.

specializations.programRequirements:
Program Requirements

Students are admitted to the Biomedical Option at the beginning of their 2A term. Enrolment is limited and students are cautioned that they must apply for admission and be admitted before registering in any of the option-required courses. In addition to the standard Computer Engineering program courses, the Biomedical Option requires completion of the following four courses:
specializations.title: Biomedical Option

specializations.programRequirements:
Program Requirements

Enrolment in the Quantum Physics Option is limited. Students must apply for admission before registering in any of its required courses. Students interested in this option should notify the Department before the Term 3A. Bridging students may also be able to take this option with appropriate scheduling. Students will be required to have a minimum cumulative GPA of 6 to enrol in the program and obtain a grade of B+ in PHYS 323. In addition to courses required for Computer Engineering, the Quantum Physics Option requires completion of the following courses:
specializations.title: Quantum Physics Option

BSC-CTSD.description: For a BSc degree in Combined Computer Science and Mathematics, students may take a Major or Honours program. MNR-CW.notes:
Program notes

  • Courses taken for the Minor cannot be used to complete the requirements of any other program. However, they can be used to satisfy co- or prerequisites. Students in the Writing Major program may not also obtain a Creative Writing Minor.
  • A student may also complete a General Program that combines a Minor in Creative Writing with one of the General or Interfaculty-Interdisciplinary General Programs in Humanities or Social Sciences. The degree will be a BA awarded by the faculty offering the General Program.

DIPL-CCON.description:
This program is offered by the Department of Art History and Visual Studies in the Faculty of Fine Arts in partnership with the Division of Continuing Studies. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

Program description

The Cultural Resource Management Program offers a Diploma in Cultural Resource Management, a Professional Specialization Certificate in Collections Management and a Professional Specialization Certificate in Visitor and Community Engagement. The program serves those who are currently involved professionally in museums, art galleries, historic sites, building conservation and related cultural stewardship activities. Students in related disciplines may also participate in program courses.

Inquiries

Please direct inquiries regarding the programs within Cultural Resource Management to:
Cultural Resource Management Program
Division of Continuing Studies
University of Victoria
Phone: 250-721-8457
Fax: 250-721-8774
Email: crmcoord@uvic.ca
Website: uvcs.uvic.ca/cultural
DIPL-CCON.subject: AHVS
DIPL-CCON.requirements:
Minimum course requirements

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • AHVS486A - Museum Principles and Practices I (1.5)
      • AHVS486B - Museum Principles and Practices II (1.5)
      • AHVS487A - Heritage Resource Management (1.5)
    • Complete 10.5 units from:
      • AHVS386 - Approaches to Collections and Museums (1.5)
      • AHVS488A - Managing Cultural Organizations (1.5)
      • AHVS488B - Collections Management (1.5)
      • AHVS488C - Communicating Through Exhibitions (1.5)
      • AHVS488D - Caring for Museum Collections (1.5)
      • AHVS488G - Public Programming (1.5)
      • AHVS488H - Topics in Museum Studies (0.5 - 1.5)
      • AHVS488I - Indigenous Cultural Stewardship (1.5)
      • AHVS488J - Contemporary Perspectives in Curatorship (1.5)
      • AHVS488K - Exhibition Planning and Design (1.5)
      • AHVS488N - Digital Planning for the Cultural Sector (1.5)
      • AHVS488S - Building Community Relationships (1.5)
      • AHVS488U - Managing Archival Collections (1.5)
      • AHVS488V - Museums as Learning Environments (1.5)
      • AHVS488W - Community Engagement and Social Change (1.5)
      • AHVS488X - Curatorial Planning and Practice (1.5)
      • AHVS488Y - Visitor Experiences (1.5)
      • AHVS489A - Heritage Area Conservation (1.5)
      • AHVS489C - Determining Significance of Heritage Resources (1.5)
      • AHVS489E - Topics in Heritage Conservation (0.5 - 1.5)
      • AHVS489G - Cultural Landscapes (1.5)
      • AHVS489H - Cultural Tourism (1.5)
      • AHVS489K - Heritage Conservation in Context (1.5)
      • AHVS489L - Heritage Conservation Planning (1.5)
      • AHVS491A - Directed Studies in Cultural Resource Management (1.5 - 3)
      • AHVS491B - Practicum in Cultural Resource Management (1.5 - 3)
DIPL-CCON.notes:
Program notes

  • The diploma program may be completed in a minimum of one calendar year. The normal period of completion is two to three years of part-time study.
  • With permission of the Department, students may register in two credentials concurrently. Courses from the Professional Specialization Certificate (PSC) in Collections Management and/or PSC in Visitor and Community Engagement may be laddered into the diploma to a maximum of 10.5 units combined. For laddering to occur, the PSC must be awarded concurrently with or prior to the diploma.
  • Credit obtained for a PSC and/or the diploma may be used in an undergraduate degree program, subject to the specific requirements of the degree program and where the PSC and/or diploma is awarded concurrently with or prior to the degree.
  • Courses taken for a PSC or for the diploma cannot be used to complete requirements for a Major, Honours, or Minor in Art History and Visual Studies, or a Minor in Museum Studies. However, they can be used to satisfy co- or pre-requisites.
  • Applicants who have previously received credit in a degree program for any of the core courses will be allowed to substitute up to 4.5 units of courses with the approval of the Cultural Resource Management Program Coordinator.
  • Up to 4.5 units of transfer credit for equivalent courses may be applied to the diploma.
  • Diploma students who fail to maintain a GPA of at least 5.0 may be asked to withdraw from the program.
  • Other students may register in individual courses in the diploma program as enrolment allows.

BSC-DSSD.description:

MNR-DSCX.notes:
Program notes

  • Some of the required courses have prerequisites that may not be in a student's Honours, Major or General program. A student may have to take additional units to complete this Minor program.
  • The selected courses must include at least 9 units numbered 200 or higher that do not form part of the requirements of the Honours or Major or General or Option Program. Any course disqualified from the Minor Program by overlap with the requirements of the Honours or Major or General or Option Program may be replaced by another Data Science topics course at the same level or higher. A Data Science topics course is defined as
    • any course listed in the Data Science Minor,
    • any STAT course,
    • any second year MATH course except 242, or
    • any MATH course from among 311, 322, 342, 346, 348, 352, 377, 379, 442, 446, 447, 449, 451, 452.
    • Requests for exceptions can be considered by the departmental advisors.
  • Only one Minor may be declared on any degree program.

BSC-EOSH.description:
This degree program is offered by the School of Earth and Ocean Sciences in the Faculty of Science. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

Professional Registration

With appropriate course selection, this program is intended to fulfill the Geoscientists Canada Knowledge Requirements for the Geology stream, which contribute the academic requirements for registration as a Professional Geoscientist (P.Geo.) through Engineers and Geoscientists British Columbia (EGBC). Students may contact either the School of Earth and Ocean Sciences or EGBC for a current list of course equivalents. EGBC academic requirements may be subject to change. EGBC has additional requirements for registration beyond academic requirements.
BSC-EOSH.subject: EOS
BSC-EOSH.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of:
      • BIOL150A - Modern Biology (1.5)
      • BIOL184 - Evolution and Biodiversity (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • CHEM101 - Fundamentals of Chemistry from Atoms to Materials (1.5)
      • CHEM150 - Engineering Chemistry (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • CHEM102 - Chemical Reactivity Fundamentals with Environmental Applications (1.5)
      • EOS110 - Oceans and Atmosphere (1.5)
      • EOS120 - The Dynamic Earth (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • MATH100 - Calculus I (1.5)
      • MATH109 - Introduction to Calculus (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MATH101 - Calculus II (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS102A - General Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS102B - General Physics II (1.5)
        • PHYS110 - Introductory Physics I (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS110 - Introductory Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS111 - Introductory Physics II (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS120 - Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS130 - Physics II (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of electives

Note

  • PHYS 110 and PHYS 111 are recommended.

Year 2

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • CHEM245 - Introduction to Thermodynamics (1.5)
      • EOS201 - Sedimentary Geology (1.5)
      • EOS202 - Structural Geology (1.5)
      • EOS205 - Mineralogy (1.5)
      • EOS210 - Introductory Geophysics (1.5)
      • EOS240 - Geochemistry (1.5)
      • EOS261 - The Climate System (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • MATH202 - Intermediate Calculus for CSC and EOS (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • MATH200 - Calculus III (1.5)
        • MATH204 - Calculus IV (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units of electives

Year 3

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • EOS300 - Earth Science Field School (1.5)
      • EOS316 - Igneous and Metamorphic Geology (1.5)
      • EOS321 - Earth History (1.5)
      • EOS330 - Paleobiology (1.5)
      • EOS335 - Isotopes in Natural Sciences (1.5)
      • EOS325 - Earth System Modelling (1.5)
    • Complete 2 of:
      • EOS311 - Biological Oceanography (1.5)
      • EOS312 - Introductory Chemical Oceanography (1.5)
      • EOS314 - Descriptive Physical Oceanography (1.5)
      • EOS340 - Atmospheric Physics (1.5)
      • EOS403 - Global Biogeochemical Cycles (1.5)
      • EOS408 - Marine Geology (1.5)
      • EOS425 - Aqueous Chemistry in the Earth and Ocean (1.5)
      • EOS431 - Physical Oceanography (1.5)
      • EOS433 - The Physics of Climate (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units of electives

Note

  • Students who choose EOS 311 should consider taking BIOL 215 as one of their electives.

Year 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • EOS400 - Advanced Field Geology (1.5)
      • EOS460 - Earth System Science (1.5)
      • EOS499A - Honours Thesis I (1.5)
      • EOS499B - Honours Thesis II (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units from EOS 300 - 499
    • Complete 4.5 units of electives

specializations.requirements:

    • EOS408 - Marine Geology (1.5)

Program requirements

The School of Earth and Ocean Sciences offers an option in Geology. Students must complete the courses noted below within the Honours program in Earth Science. The declared option will appear on students' transcripts.
specializations.title: Geology Option

BSC-EOSH.notes:
Program notes

  • Students who have completed Biology 11 and 12 should take BIOL 184.
  • EOS 403, 408, 416, 420, 423, 425, 427, 431, 433, 440 and 450 are normally offered in alternate years. Students are advised to consult with the school to determine when these courses are offered.
  • Students seeking to fulfill EGBC Academic Requirements (Geology) should select two of EOS 416, 423 or 450 as electives, or remote sensing, GIS or geomorphology electives from GEOG, with close attention to EGBC requirements.
  • Students completing the Minor in Ocean Sciences may substitute two 300- or 400-level EOS courses in lieu of two of EOS 311, 312, 314, 403, 408, 425, 431, 433.
  • The following geology option is available to students wishing to pursue further in the subject area.

BSC-ECSM.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Economics in the Faculty of Social Sciences. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BSC-ECSM.subject: ECON
BSC-ECSM.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON103 - Principles of Microeconomics (1.5)
      • ECON103C - Introduction to Principles of Microeconomics and Financial Project Evaluation (1.5)
      • ECON180 - Introduction to Economics and Financial Project Evaluation (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON104 - Principles of Macroeconomics (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • CSC105 - Computers and Information Processing (1.5)
      • CSC110 - Fundamentals of Programming I (1.5)
      • CSC111 - Fundamentals of Programming with Engineering Applications (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • MATH100 - Calculus I (1.5)
      • MATH109 - Introduction to Calculus (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MATH101 - Calculus II (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      ANTH, ES (not ES 312), GEOG, POLI, PSYC, SOCI, SOSC, PHIL 220, 223. A course in statistics or quantitative methods will not count toward this requirement.
    • Complete 6 units of electives

Year 2

  • Complete all of the following
    • Earn a minimum grade of C in each of the following:
      • ECON203 - Intermediate Microeconomics I (1.5)
      • ECON204 - Intermediate Macroeconomics (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON225 - Writing for Economists (1.5)
      • ENGR240 - Technical Writing (1.5)
    • Earned a minimum grade of C+ in 1 of:
      • ECON245 - Descriptive Statistics and Probability (1.5)
      • STAT260 - Introduction to Probability and Statistics I (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON246 - Statistical Inference (1.5)
      • STAT261 - Introduction to Probability and Statistics II (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MATH200 - Calculus III (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • MATH110 - Matrix Algebra for Engineers (1.5)
      • MATH211 - Matrix Algebra I (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units of electives

Years 3 and 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON313 - Intermediate Microeconomics II (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON365 - Econometrics: Part I (1.5)
      • ECON366 - Econometrics: Part II (1.5)
    • Earn a minimum grade of C in each of the following:
      • ECON350 - Mathematical Economics I: An Introduction to Static Methods (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON351 - Mathematical Economics II: An Introduction to Dynamic Methods (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units of:
      ECON 300-499 (CE 300 can be substituted for 1.5 units).
    • Complete 3 units of:
      ECON 400-499
    • Complete 15 units of electives

specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

This option is intended for students who wish to supplement studies in Economics with studies having a focus on Finance.
specializations.title: Finance Option

BSC-ECSM.notes:
Program notes

  • ECON 225 and the Mathematics requirement for the Major program should normally be completed by the end of the second year.
  • CSC 105 is intended primarily for students in Economics or the School of Business.
  • ECON 245 and 246 (or STAT 260 and 261) should normally be completed by the end of Year 3.
  • Students wishing to proceed to graduate studies in Economics are advised to include ECON 400 and 401 in their program. Students in the BSc Major program require permission from the department to register in ECON 400 and 401.

BA-ECAH.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Economics in the Faculty of Social Sciences. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BA-ECAH.subject: ECON
BA-ECAH.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Earned a minimum grade of B in 1 of:
      • ECON103 - Principles of Microeconomics (1.5)
      • ECON103C - Introduction to Principles of Microeconomics and Financial Project Evaluation (1.5)
      • ECON180 - Introduction to Economics and Financial Project Evaluation (1.5)
    • Earn a minimum grade of B in each of the following:
      • ECON104 - Principles of Macroeconomics (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • CSC105 - Computers and Information Processing (1.5)
      • CSC110 - Fundamentals of Programming I (1.5)
      • CSC111 - Fundamentals of Programming with Engineering Applications (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • MATH100 - Calculus I (1.5)
      • MATH102 - Calculus for Students in the Social and Biological Sciences (1.5)
      • MATH109 - Introduction to Calculus (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      ANTH, ES (not ES 312), GEOG, POLI, PSYC, SOCI, SOSC, PHIL 220, 223. A course in statistics or quantitative methods will not count toward this requirement.
    • Complete 7.5 units of electives

Year 2

  • Complete all of the following
    • Earn a minimum grade of B+ in each of the following:
      • ECON203 - Intermediate Microeconomics I (1.5)
      • ECON204 - Intermediate Macroeconomics (1.5)
    • Earned a minimum grade of B+ in 1 of:
      • ECON225 - Writing for Economists (1.5)
      • ENGR240 - Technical Writing (1.5)
    • Earned a minimum grade of B in 1 of:
      • ECON245 - Descriptive Statistics and Probability (1.5)
      • STAT260 - Introduction to Probability and Statistics I (1.5)
    • Earned a minimum grade of B- in 1 of:
      • ECON246 - Statistical Inference (1.5)
      • STAT261 - Introduction to Probability and Statistics II (1.5)
    • Earn a minimum grade of B+ in each of the following:
      • ECON313 - Intermediate Microeconomics II (1.5)
    • Complete 6 units of electives

Year 3

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON333 - Introduction to Economic Growth (1.5)
      • ECON401 - Advanced Topics in Macroeconomic Theory (1.5)
      • ECON405B - International Monetary Theory and Policy (1.5)
      • ECON406 - Monetary Economics (1.5)
      • ECON410B - Problems of Canadian Macroeconomic Policy (1.5)
      • ECON453 - Economic Growth (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON321 - The Economic History of Canada (1.5)
      • ECON327 - Economic History of North America (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON345 - Applied Econometrics I (1.5)
      • ECON365 - Econometrics: Part I (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON346 - Applied Econometrics II (1.5)
      • ECON366 - Econometrics: Part II (1.5)
    • Complete 3.0 units of:
      ECON 300-499 (CE 300 can be substituted for 1.5 units).
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      300- or 400-level courses other than ECON.
    • Complete 4.5 units of electives

Year 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON499 - Fourth-Year Honours Thesis and Seminar (3.0)
    • Complete 1.5 units from ECON 400 - 499
    • Complete 6 units from ECON 300 - 499
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      300- or 400-level courses other than ECON.
    • Complete 3 units of electives

specializations.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON305 - Money and Banking (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON435 - Financial Economics (1.5)
      • ECON454 - Theory of Corporate Finance (1.5)
    • Complete 2 of:
      • COM425 - Taxation for Managers (1.5)
      • COM426 - Management Accounting II (1.5)
      • COM445 - Corporate Finance and Valuation (1.5)
      • COM446 - Investments (1.5)
      • ECON405B - International Monetary Theory and Policy (1.5)
      • ECON406 - Monetary Economics (1.5)
      • ECON413 - Economics of Firm Strategy (1.5)
      • ECON435 - Financial Economics (1.5)
      • ECON454 - Theory of Corporate Finance (1.5)
      • ECON468 - Financial Econometrics (1.5)
      • IB417 - International Finance (1.5)
      • MATH348 - Numerical Methods (1.5)
      • MATH477 - Stochastic Financial Modelling (1.5)
specializations.concentrationProgramNotes:
Program notes

  • Both ECON 435 and 454 may be included in the Finance Option.
  • COM 425, 426, 445, 446, IB 417 cannot be used in both the Finance Option and the Business Minor.
specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

This option is intended for students who wish to supplement studies in Economics with studies having a focus on Finance.
specializations.title: Finance Option

BA-ECAH.notes:
Program notes

  • ECON 225 and the Mathematics requirement for the Major program should normally be completed by the end of the second year.
  • It is strongly recommended that ECON 245 and 246 (or STAT 260 and 261) be completed by the end of Year 2.
  • ECON 345 and 346 or ECON 365 and 366 must be completed by the end of Year 3.
  • CSC 105 is intended primarily for students in Economics or the School of Business.
  • Students wishing to proceed to graduate studies in Economics are advised to include ECON 400 and 401 in their program. Students in the BA Honours program require permission from the department to register in ECON 400 and 401.
  • Students are encouraged to take an additional course in Year 3 as ECON 499 in Year 4 is very time intensive.
  • Transfer students are encouraged to enroll in ECON 313 as soon as possible.
  • ECON 345 or ECON 365 must be taken prior to ECON 346. ECON 365 must be taken prior to ECON 366.

BSC-ECSH.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Economics in the Faculty of Social Sciences. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BSC-ECSH.subject: ECON
BSC-ECSH.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following

    • Complete 1 of:
      • CSC105 - Computers and Information Processing (1.5)
      • CSC110 - Fundamentals of Programming I (1.5)

    • Complete 1 of:
      • MATH100 - Calculus I (1.5)
      • MATH109 - Introduction to Calculus (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MATH101 - Calculus II (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      ANTH, ES (not ES 312), GEOG, POLI, PSYC, SOCI, SOSC, PHIL 220, 223. A course in statistics or quantitative methods will not count toward this requirement.
    • Complete 6 units of electives

Year 2

  • Complete all of the following
    • Earn a minimum grade of B+ in each of the following:
      • ECON203 - Intermediate Microeconomics I (1.5)
      • ECON204 - Intermediate Macroeconomics (1.5)
    • Earned a minimum grade of B+ in 1 of:

Year 3

  • Complete all of the following

    • Complete all of:
      • ECON351 - Mathematical Economics II: An Introduction to Dynamic Methods (1.5)
      • ECON365 - Econometrics: Part I (1.5)
      • ECON366 - Econometrics: Part II (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units of:
      ECON 300-499 (CE 300 can be substituted for 1.5 units).
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      300- or 400-level courses other than Economics
    • Complete 4.5 units of electives

Year 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON400 - Advanced Topics in Microeconomic Theory (1.5)
      • ECON401 - Advanced Topics in Macroeconomic Theory (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON499 - Fourth-Year Honours Thesis and Seminar (3.0)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      300- or 400-level courses other than Economics.
    • Complete 4.5 units of:
      Econ 400-499
    • Complete 3 units of electives

specializations.concentrationProgramNotes:
Program notes

  • Both ECON 435 and 454 may be included in the Finance Option.
  • COM 425, 426, 445, 446, IB 417 cannot be used in both the Finance Option and the Business Minor.
  • For Faculty of Business courses, check course availability online. For courses numbered 400 and above, fill out a ‘Single Course Application’ available online.
  • Students interested in an accounting career should consult the Careers section on the Department of Economics undergraduate web page.

BSC-ECSH.notes:
Program notes

  • ECON 225 and the Mathematics requirement for the Major program should normally be completed by the end of the second year.
  • CSC 105 is intended primarily for students in Economics or the School of Business.
  • It is strongly recommended that ECON 245 and 246 (or STAT 260 and 261) be completed by the end of Year 2.
  • ECON 365 and 366, and ECON 350 and 351 must be completed by the end of Year 3.
  • Students are encouraged to take an additional course in Year 3 as ECON 499 in Year 4 is very time intensive.
  • Transfer students are encouraged to enroll in ECON 313 as soon as possible.

MNR-ECON.description: This program is offered by the Department of Economics in the Faculty of Social Sciences. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
MNR-ECON.subject: ECON
MNR-ECON.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON103 - Principles of Microeconomics (1.5)
      • ECON103C - Introduction to Principles of Microeconomics and Financial Project Evaluation (1.5)
      • ECON180 - Introduction to Economics and Financial Project Evaluation (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON104 - Principles of Macroeconomics (1.5)

Year 2

  • Complete all of:
    • ECON225 - Writing for Economists (1.5)

Years 3 and 4

  • Complete 9 units from ECON 300 - 499
MNR-ECON.notes:
Program notes

  • Students completing a Major in a writing-intensive field may apply to the Economics Adviser to have the ECON 225 program requirement waived.
  • Only one Minor may be declared on any degree program.

MNR-EDUX.description: This program is offered by the Department of Curriculum and Instruction in the Faculty of Education. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
MNR-EDUX.subject: ED
MNR-EDUX.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • EDUC100 - Introduction to Education (1.5)
      • EDCI335 - Learning Design for Technology-Mediated Environments (1.5)
      • ED-P301 - Internship/Community Experience (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units of:
      approved electives (see below). At least 3.0 units must be taken at the 300 or 400-level.

Approved electives

  • Select from:
    • AE306 - Painting (1.5)
    • AE310 - Introduction to Applied Design (1.5)
    • AE314 - Introduction to Community Art Education (1.5)
    • AE315 - Curriculum Planning in Art Education (1.5)
    • AE317 - Responding to Art (1.5)
    • AE322 - Digital Arts (1.5)
    • AE330 - Visual Design for Marketing, Advocacy and Persuasion (1.5)
    • EDCI338 - Social Media and Personalized Learning (1.5)
    • EDCI339 - Distributed and Open Learning (1.5)
    • EDCI356 - Expanding Notions of Text (1.5)
    • EPHE142 - Personal Health, Wellness and Potential (1.5)
    • EPHE242 - Introduction to Human Cellular Physiology (1.5)
    • EPHE246 - Strategies for Active Health (1.5)
    • EPHE253 - Program Planning (1.5)
    • EPHE270 - Foundations of Outdoor Recreation (1.5)
    • EPHE348 - Psychology of Physical Activity (1.5)
    • EPHE351 - Community and Population Health (1.5)
    • ED-D101 - Learning Strategies for University Success (1.5)
    • ED-D316 - Study of Communication in Interpersonal Relationships (1.5)
    • ED-D414 - Group Processes (1.5)
    • ED-D417 - Skills for Effective Interpersonal Communication (1.5)
    • ED-D418 - Introduction to Theories of Counselling (1.5)
    • ED-D423 - Approaches to Cross-Cultural Education (1.5)
    • IED371 - The History of Indigenous Education in Canada (1.5)
    • IED372 - Indigenous Epistemologies (1.5)
    • IET420 - Topics in Intercultural Education (1.5)
    • IET430 - Facilitating Intercultural Relationships (1.5)

Note

  • The electives are oriented towards communication, marketing, or teaching and learning. Other electives may be approved by the program lead.
MNR-EDUX.notes:
Program notes

  • 200, 300 and 400-level courses taken for the Minor cannot be used to complete requirements for any other degree program. They can, however, be used to satisfy corequisites or prerequisites. Overlapped courses must be replaced by another course at the same level or higher with permission of the department.

BENG-ELEC.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in the Faculty of Engineering and Computer Science. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BENG-ELEC.subject: ECE
BENG-ELEC.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • CHEM150 - Engineering Chemistry (1.5)
      • CSC111 - Fundamentals of Programming with Engineering Applications (1.5)
      • ENGR110 - Design and Communication I (2.5)
      • ENGR120 - Design and Communication II (2.5)
      • ENGR130 - Introduction to Professional Practice (0.5)
      • ENGR141 - Engineering Mechanics (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • MATH100 - Calculus I (1.5)
      • MATH109 - Introduction to Calculus (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MATH101 - Calculus II (1.5)
      • MATH110 - Matrix Algebra for Engineers (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS110 - Introductory Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS111 - Introductory Physics II (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS122 - Mechanics for Engineers (1.5)
        • PHYS125 - Fundamentals of Physics (1.5)

Note

  • Students normally must successfully complete ENGR 130 (Introduction to Professional Practice) before undertaking their first work term.

Year 2

  • Complete all of:
    • CSC116 - Fundamentals of Programming with Engineering Applications II (1.5)
    • ECE216 - Electricity and Magnetism (1.5)
    • ECE220 - Electrical Properties of Materials (1.5)
    • ECE241 - Digital Design (1.5)
    • ECE250 - Linear Circuits I (1.5)
    • ECE255 - Introduction to Computer Architecture (1.5)
    • ECE260 - Continuous-Time Signals and Systems (1.5)
    • ECE299 - Introduction to Electrical and Computer Engineering Design (1.5)
    • MATH200 - Calculus III (1.5)
    • MATH204 - Calculus IV (1.5)
    • MECH295 - Engineering Fundamentals (1.5)
    • STAT254 - Probability and Statistics for Engineers (1.5)

Notes

  • CSC 115 may be substituted in a term when CSC 116 is not offered. CSC 116 is strongly recommended.
  • Students entering the Electrical Engineering program through the Engineering Bridge program must take MECH 295 as their Natural Science Elective.

Year 3

  • Complete all of:
    • CSC349A - Numerical Analysis (1.5)
    • ECE300 - Linear Circuits II (1.5)
    • ECE310 - Digital Signal Processing I (1.5)
    • ECE320 - Electronic Devices I (1.5)
    • ECE330 - Electronic Circuits I (1.5)
    • ECE340 - Applied Electromagnetics and Photonics (1.5)
    • ECE350 - Communications Theory and Systems I (1.5)
    • ECE355 - Microprocessor-Based Systems (1.5)
    • ECE360 - Control Theory and Systems I (1.5)
    • ECE370 - Electromechanical Energy Conversion (1.5)
    • ECE380 - Electronic Circuits II (1.5)
    • ECE399 - Design Project I (1.5)

Year 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ECE499 - Design Project II (1.5)
      • ECON180 - Introduction to Economics and Financial Project Evaluation (1.5)
      • ENGR297 - Technology and Society (1.5)
      • ENGR446 - Technical Report (1.0)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Complementary Studies Electives. A course deals with central issues in humanities or social sciences, as required by CEAB guidelines for complementary studies, and as approved by the Faculty of Engineering and Computer Science. Students may choose a course from a pre-approved list www.uvic.ca/engineering/undergraduate/advising/planning/index.php or seek permission from the Engineering Undergraduate Office (EUO).
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Natural Science Electives. A course in natural science as required by CEAB guidelines and as approved by the Faculty of Engineering and Computer Science. Students may choose a course from a pre-approved list: www.uvic.ca/engineering/ece/current/undergraduate/advising/science-elective/index.php or seek permission from the Engineering Undergraduate Office (EUO).
    • Complete 10.5 units of:
      Technical Electives

Notes

  • ENGR 297 may also be completed in other years.
  • Students normally take ENGR 446 in the term preceding the final term of their academic program (academic or work term.)
  • A list of technical electives, and the terms in which they are normally offered, can be found at www.uvic.ca/engineering/ece/current/undergraduate/advising/schedule. Not all technical electives will be offered every year. Some electives may be offered in a different term than listed.

specializations.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • BME200 - Molecular and Cellular Physiology for Engineers (1.5)
        • BME201 - Quantitative Human Physiology (1.5)
      • Complete all of the following
        • Complete all of:
          • BIOL225 - Principles of Cell Biology (1.5)

  • BIOL 190A or BIOL 186 and BIOL 225 cover prerequisite material necessary for admission to the medical program at UBC. Please refer to the UBC medical program requirements at mdprogram.med.ubc.ca/admissions/admission-requirements.
