specializations.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • PHYS215 - Introductory Quantum Physics (1.5)
    • Earn a minimum grade of B+ in each of the following:
      • PHYS323 - Quantum Mechanics I (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • PHYS423 - Quantum Mechanics II (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • MATH342 - Intermediate Ordinary Differential Equations (1.5)
      • PHYS321A - Classical Mechanics I (1.5)
      • PHYS328 - Solid State Physics I (1.5)
specializations.concentrationProgramNotes:
Program notes

  • A course in this option may be replaced with another course relevant to this option with the permission of the Department.
specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

Enrolment in the Quantum Physics Option is limited. Students must apply for admission before registering in any of its required courses. Students interested in this option should notify the Department before the Term 3A. Bridging students may also be able to take this option with appropriate scheduling. Students will be required to have a minimum cumulative GPA of 6 to enrol in the program and obtain a grade of B+ in PHYS 323. In addition to courses required for Electrical Engineering, the Quantum Physics Option requires completion of the following courses:
specializations.title: Quantum Physics Option

BENG-ELEC.notes:
Program options

The following options are available to students wishing to pursue further in the subject area covered by an option.

MNR-ELSY.description: This program is offered by the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in the Faculty of Engineering and Computer Science. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
MNR-ELSY.subject: ECE

BED-ELEM.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Curriculum and Instruction in the Faculty of Education. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BED-ELEM.subject: EDCI
BED-ELEM.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
      Approved English
    • Complete 2 of:
      • ATWP135 - Academic Reading and Writing (1.5)
      • ENSH101 - Themes in Literature (AWR) (1.5)
      • ENSH102 - Literature in Action (AWR) (1.5)
      • Approved Canadian studies
    • Complete 2 of:
      • CS102 - Introduction to Canadian Contemporary Issues (1.5)
      • CS201 - Issues and Ideas in Canadian Environmentalism (1.5)
      • ECON100 - The Canadian Economy - Problems and Policies (1.5)
      • HSTR230A - Canada to Confederation (1.5)
      • HSTR230B - Canada from Confederation - present (1.5)
      • POLI101 - Canadian Politics (1.5)
      • POLI201 - Canadian Institutions of Government (1.5)
      • SOCI103 - Settler Colonialism and Canadian Society (1.5)
      • Approved laboratory science
    • Complete all of the following
      • Complete 2 of:
        • ASTR101 - Exploring the Night Sky (1.5)
        • ASTR102 - Exploring the Cosmos (1.5)
        • BIOL184 - Evolution and Biodiversity (1.5)
        • BIOL186 - Physiology and Cell Biology (1.5)
        • EOS110 - Oceans and Atmosphere (1.5)
        • EOS120 - The Dynamic Earth (1.5)
        • EPHE141 - Human Anatomy (1.5)
        • EPHE241 - Introduction to Human Systemic Physiology (1.5)
        • GEOG103 - Introduction to Physical Geography (1.5)
      • Students may use either EPHE 141 or EPHE 241 as an approved laboratory science course, but not both.
      • EOS 120 is recommended as it includes a lab designed for prospective teachers. Courses completed more than ten years ago are not normally accepted.
      • Approved mathematics
    • Complete all of the following
      • Complete 2 of:
        • MATH100 - Calculus I (1.5)
        • MATH101 - Calculus II (1.5)
        • MATH102 - Calculus for Students in the Social and Biological Sciences (1.5)
        • MATH151 - Finite Mathematics (1.5)
        • MATH161 - Mathematics for Elementary School Teachers I (1.5)
        • MATH162 - Mathematics for Elementary School Teachers II (1.5)
      • A minimum grade-point average of 3.0 (C+) is required in the approved mathematics courses to demonstrate competency in mathematics.
      • Students may take either MATH 100 or MATH 102, but not both.
      • MATH 161 and MATH 162 are recommended.
      • Courses completed more than ten years ago are not normally accepted.
      • Approved electives
    • Complete 3 units of:
      approved electives, normally not from the Faculty of Education, to be completed in year one or a subsequent summer session. The electives must be completed before entry to year four. Choose courses related to subjects taught in BC schools. For example, computer science, environmental studies, French, Indigenous Studies. From the Faculty of Education, a student may take EPHE 141 or 155. Consult an adviser before registering in any other Faculty of Education course.

Notes

  • Students must demonstrate competency in written English (refer Written English Competency Requirement).
  • A sessional grade-point average of at least 3.0 (C+) on the most recent session is required or, if that session is less than 12 units, a grade-point average of at least 3.0 on the most recent 12 units.

Year 2

  • Complete all of:
    • ED-D301 - Learners and Learning Environments (1.5)
    • EDCI250 - Elementary Field Experience Seminar I (1.5)
    • ED-P251 - Three-Week Practicum (Elementary Education) (1.5)
    • EDCI300 - Mathematical Processes A (1.5)
    • EDCI302 - Literacy and Language in Elementary or Middle School (1.5)
    • EDCI303 - Historical and Philosophical Foundations of Canadian Education (1.5)
    • EDCI305A - Drama Education as a Medium for Learning I (1.5)
    • EDCI306A - Music in the Elementary Classroom I (1.5)
    • EDCI307A - Art in the Elementary or Middle Classroom I (1.5)
    • EDCI336 - Technology and Innovation in Education (1.5)
    • EPHE310 - Physical Education for General Classroom Teachers I (1.5)
    • EPHE311 - Physical Education for General Classroom Teachers II (1.5)

Year 3

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ED-D407 - Evaluating and Reporting Student Progress (1.5)
      • ED-D408 - Promoting Prosocial Behaviour: Strategies and Management (1.5)
      • ED-D420 - Learning Support: Context and Key Issues (1.5)
      • EDCI330 - Elementary Field Experience Seminar II (1.5)
      • ED-P351 - Six-Week Practicum (Elementary Education) (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • EDCI402 - Reading Instructional Principles and Strategies (1.5)
      • EDCI403 - Curriculum and Instruction in Elementary or Middle School Science (1.5)
      • EDCI404 - Curriculum and Instruction in Elementary School Social Studies (1.5)
      • EDCI405 - Mathematical Processes B (1.5)
      • IED373 - EL TELNIWT and Indigenous Education (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • EDCI469 - Teaching Oral French (1.5)
      • EDCI476 - Organization and Instruction in French Immersion (1.5)

Year 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ED-D410 - Teacher as Leader: The Professional Role (1.5)
      • ED-P451 - Final Practicum (Elementary Education) (3.0)
      • EDCI490 - Transformative Inquiry (1.5)
      • EDCI447 - Principles of Teaching English Language Learning (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • EDCI305B - Drama Education as a Medium for Learning II (1.5)
      • EDCI306B - Music in the Elementary Classroom II (1.5)
      • EDCI307B - Art in the Elementary Classroom II (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units of:
      Approved upper-level Education electives

BA-ENAM.notes:
Breadth Recommendations

  • 1.5 units prior to 1660 (ENSH 346-ENSH 355)
  • 1.5 units between 1660-1900 (ENSH 359- ENSH 366, ENSH 376, ENSH 384)
  • 1.5 units after 1900 (ENSH 369-ENSH 372, ENSH 377-ENSH 378, ENSH 380, ENSH 385-ENSH 386, ENSH 390, ENSH 395)
  • 1.5 units of American, Canadian, Indigenous or World Literature (ENSH 376-ENSH 395)
  • 1.5 units of genre, form, or themed courses (ENSH 310-ENSH 342)

Program notes

  • Three units of Professional Communication courses (ENSH 203, 302, 305, 306, 308, 309, 400, 401, 402, 403, 404, 405, 406) can be counted towards the English Major requirements.

specializations.concentrationProgramNotes:
Program notes

  • Students who have credit for courses in English not included in the current Calendar should see the Literature or Professional Communication Adviser for information.
specializations.description: This program is designed for students completing an English Honours program and who wish to combine their study of literature with courses that teach the writing skills valuable in the high-technology workplace, including the ability to use new media to solve the problems of professional communication.
specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

Students who wish formally to declare this program must submit a Record of Degree Program form to the Advising Centre after the minimum grades in the first- and second-year English courses have been obtained.

The following requirements are in addition to those of the Honours Program.
specializations.title: Professional Communication Option

BA-ENAH.notes:
Program notes

  • ENSH 301 should be taken in Year 2 if possible.
  • ENSH 490 is recommended before ENSH 499 but not required.
  • Three units of Professional Communication courses (ENSH 203, 302, 305, 306, 308, 309, 400, 401, 402, 403, 404, 405, 406) can be counted towards the English Honours requirements.

BA-ESAM.description: This degree program is offered by the School of Environmental Studies in the Faculty of Social Sciences. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BA-ESAM.subject: ES
BA-ESAM.requirements:
Lower-level

  • Complete all of the following
    • Earn a minimum grade of B- in each of the following:
      • ES200 - Introduction to Environmental Studies (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • ES240 - Ecological Processes (1.5)

Upper-level

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ES301 - Political Ecology (1.5)
      • ES321 - Ethnoecology (1.5)
      • ES341 - Past, Present, and Future Ecologies (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      upper-level coursework with a strong emphasis on field or experiential learning selected from the "Approved field and experiential courses" list below.
    • Complete 9 units from ES 300 - 499

Approved field and experiential courses

  • Select from:
    • ER312A - Field Study in Ecological Restoration I (1.5)
    • ER312B - Field Study in Ecological Restoration II (1.5)
    • ER412 - Galiano Island Field Study (1.5)
    • ES378 - Leadership Skills for Change (1.5)

BA-ESAM.notes:
Program notes

  • The Major in Environmental Studies must be combined with another Honours or Major program.
  • The courses required for the other Honours or Major program will replace electives listed in this program.
  • Up to 3 units of 300- and 400-level coursework from other departments and schools may be used, subject to approval by the undergraduate adviser. Approved courses include: ANTH 302, BIOL 334, CE 300, EDCI 454, EOS 365, 300- and 400-level ER coursework, GEOG 304, 314, 357, 358, 371, 450, 453, 456, 457, HDCC 300, 390, 400, HSTR 325, POLI 357, 458, PSYC 325.
  • Up to 3 units can be taken from other accredited postsecondary institutions, subject to approval by the ES undergraduate adviser.
  • Up to 4.5 units of ER courses (in addition to the ES and RNS cross-listed courses) may be applied to an Environmental Studies Major.

BSC-FESC.description: This single degree program is composed of a selected combination of courses from the Department of Mathematics and Statistics and the Department of Economics. Students may complete this program in either the Faculty of Social Sciences or the Faculty of Science. Those choosing a Social Science degree should consult the Social Sciences Faculty Program Requirements; those choosing a Science degree should must consult the Science Faculty Program Requirements.
BSC-FESC.subject: ECON
BSC-FESC.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • CSC110 - Fundamentals of Programming I (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON103 - Principles of Microeconomics (1.5)
      • ECON103C - Introduction to Principles of Microeconomics and Financial Project Evaluation (1.5)
      • ECON180 - Introduction to Economics and Financial Project Evaluation (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON104 - Principles of Macroeconomics (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • MATH100 - Calculus I (1.5)
      • MATH109 - Introduction to Calculus (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MATH101 - Calculus II (1.5)
      • MATH122 - Logic and Foundations (1.5)
      • MATH211 - Matrix Algebra I (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units of:
      Academic Writing Requirement and electives

Year 2

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of:
      • COM202 - Financial Accounting I (1.5)
      • COM270 - Financial and Management Accounting For Specialists (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • COM240 - Management Finance (1.5)
    • Earn a minimum grade of C in each of the following:
      • ECON203 - Intermediate Microeconomics I (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON204 - Intermediate Macroeconomics (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON225 - Writing for Economists (1.5)
      • ENGR240 - Technical Writing (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MATH200 - Calculus III (1.5)
      • MATH204 - Calculus IV (1.5)
      • MATH248 - Computer Assisted Mathematics (1.5)
      • STAT260 - Introduction to Probability and Statistics I (1.5)
      • STAT261 - Introduction to Probability and Statistics II (1.5)

Year 3

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON305 - Money and Banking (1.5)
      • ECON365 - Econometrics: Part I (1.5)
      • ECON366 - Econometrics: Part II (1.5)
      • ECON435 - Financial Economics (1.5)
      • MATH348 - Numerical Methods (1.5)
      • MATH377 - Mathematical Modelling (1.5)
      • STAT350 - Mathematical Statistics I (1.5)
    • Earn a minimum grade of B- in each of the following:
      • ECON313 - Intermediate Microeconomics II (1.5)
    • Complete 3.0 units of electives

Year 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ECON454 - Theory of Corporate Finance (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ECON468 - Financial Econometrics (1.5)
      • STAT457 - Time Series Analysis (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units from ECON or MATH 300 - 499
    • Complete all of:
      • MATH452 - Stochastic Processes (1.5)
      • MATH477 - Stochastic Financial Modelling (1.5)
      • STAT450 - Mathematical Statistics II (1.5)
    • Complete 6 units of electives
BSC-FESC.notes:
Program notes

  • Satisfaction of the Academic Writing Requirement is a prerequisite for ECON 225. ECON 225 is a prerequisite for ECON 313 and a co-requisite for ECON 365.

BA-GLAH.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Greek and Roman Studies in the Faculty of Humanities. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

Years 1 and 2

  • PHIL 301 and 303 are acceptable for credit in all programs in the Department of Greek and Roman Studies in lieu of any 300-level course in Greek and Roman Studies.

MNR-HESO.description: This is an interdisciplinary program that combines course work from more than one discipline. Refer to Interdisciplinary Programs for more information.
MNR-HESO.subject: HS
MNR-HESO.requirements:
Minimum course requirements

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 3 units of:
      Introductory course work in social and/or biomedical approaches to health from an approved list
    • Complete all of:
      • HS200 - Health and Society (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units of:
      electives numbered 300 and above from the approved list of theory and methods courses
    • Complete 3 units of:
      specialization courses numbered 300 and above from one of the approved list of courses in Aboriginal health, addictions and mental health, aging, disability, and children and youth
    • Complete 1.5 of:
      • HS400A - Directed Experiential Learning in Health and Society: Research (1.5)
      • HS400B - Directed Experiential Learning in Health and Society: Community Service (1.5)

Notes

  • Approved course lists can be found on the program website: www.uvic.ca/interdisciplinary/healthsociety/undergraduate/electives/index.php
  • No more than two courses can be taken from the same academic unit to fulfill elective or specialization credits.
MNR-HESO.notes:
Program notes

  • By completing the requirements for the General program together with an Honours, Major, or General program, students may obtain a Minor.
  • No more than 3 units of the required 300-and 400-level course work can be taken at another institution and at least 6 of the required units must be completed at UVic. The 9 units of required 300- and 400-level course work cannot form part of the 300- and 400-level department requirements for a student’s Honours, Major, or General Program; co-requisite courses in other programs may be counted toward the Minor.
  • Inquiries about this program, its prerequisites or its list of approved electives or prerequisites can be directed to the Health & Society Minor Program Director (healthdirector@uvic.ca) or the Interdisciplinary Program Assistant (idpassis@uvic.ca).

  • Please note that some of these courses may require prerequisites.
BSC-HINF.notes:
To meet the requirements of the degree in Health Information Science, students must complete:

  1. 60 units comprising core, elective, and senior elective courses, and
  2. a minimum of three Co-op work terms. The granting of work term credit by challenge is not normally permitted.

Work term placements are across Canada and students must be prepared to accept placements outside Victoria. All students are expected to attend the health informatics Co-op course: HINF 202 Introduction to Professional Practice.

BA-HSAH.notes:
Program notes

The Honours Seminar (HSTR 496) explores historical theory and methods, and the Honours Thesis (HSTR 499) is a research project normally based on primary sources. HSTR 499 includes an oral examination conducted by a committee comprising the faculty supervisor of the paper and a second reader, as well as the departmental Honours Adviser (or the adviser’s representative) acting as chair. Together these are designed to expand understanding of both the content and the craft of history. Students in the Program may also choose to write a Third-Year Honours Essay (HSTR 497).

DIPL-ICDG.description:
This program is offered by the School of Public Administration in the Faculty of Human and Social Development. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

Note: Delivery of this program is subject to enrolment and funding. Please visit the School of Public Administration website for full application and program details.

The School of Public Administration offers a part-time 10-course Diploma in Indigenous Community Development and Governance program. The program is designed for learners who are employed or seeking employment in Indigenous governments or organizations. Courses are delivered online.

Learners will acquire the skills and background necessary for effective and responsible management and will broaden their understanding of the administrative process. Online program delivery will take into account multiple learning styles and circumstances with online lectures, guest speakers, and readings available through texts and online library articles. Instructors will encourage peer support and cross learning.

The learning will be applicable to the students’ workplaces and is designed for full-time administrators. Students may choose to enroll in one or two courses per term.

The Diploma will be awarded upon successful completion of the program (15 units) with an overall GPA of at least 2.0.
DIPL-ICDG.subject: ICDG
DIPL-ICDG.requirements:
Minimum course requirements

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ICDG301 - Indigenous Governance in Canada (1.5)
      • ICDG402 - Intergovernmental Relations: Working with Others (1.5)
    • Complete 8 of:
      • ICDG302 - Communications in Indigenous Governments and Organizations (1.5)
      • ICDG303 - Lands, Resources, and Economic Development (1.5)
      • ICDG304 - Strategic Planning and Implementation (1.5)
      • ICDG305 - Indigenous Research and Project Management (1.5)
      • ICDG306 - Human Resource Management in Indigenous Organizations (1.5)
      • ICDG307 - Managing Change for Effective Social and Community Development (1.5)
      • ICDG308 - Financial Management in Indigenous Governments and Organizations (1.5)
      • ICDG400 - Leadership in Indigenous Communities and Governments (1.5)
      • ICDG401 - Capstone Project for Indigenous Governments and Organizations (1.5)
    • With permission of the School, students may complete three elective ICDG courses and up to two other 300 or 400-level UVic courses on relevant Indigenous Studies or Public Administration topic.

PSC-ICDG*.description:
This program is offered by the School of Public Administration in the Faculty of Human and Social Development. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

Please visit the School of Public Administration website for full application and program details.

The School of Public Administration offers a part-time, four course, Professional Specialization Certificate in Indigenous Community Development and Governance. The program is designed for learners who are employed or seeking employment in Indigenous governments or organizations, as well as public servants who require the knowledge and skills to work effectively and efficiently with Indigenous citizens and Indigenous governments. Courses are delivered online.

Learners will acquire the skills necessary for effective and responsible management and will broaden their understanding of the administrative process. Program delivery will take into account multiple learning styles and circumstances and may include online lectures, guest speakers, and readings available through texts and online library articles. Instructors will encourage peer support and cross learning.

The learning will be applicable to the students’ workplaces and is designed for full-time administrators. Students may choose to enrol in one or two courses per term.

PSC-ICDG*.requirements:

      • ICDG304 - Strategic Planning and Implementation (1.5)
      • ICDG305 - Indigenous Research and Project Management (1.5)
      • ICDG306 - Human Resource Management in Indigenous Organizations (1.5)
      • ICDG307 - Managing Change for Effective Social and Community Development (1.5)
      • ICDG308 - Financial Management in Indigenous Governments and Organizations (1.5)
      • ICDG400 - Leadership in Indigenous Communities and Governments (1.5)

MNR-ICDG.description:

Please contact the School of Public Administration for more application and program details at: pamanager@uvic.ca.

The School of Public Administration offers a Minor in Indigenous Community Development and Governance (ICDG) to students enrolled in other undergraduate programs at UVic. The minor program is designed for learners who are employed or seeking employment in Indigenous governments or organizations, as well as future public servants who require the knowledge and skills to work effectively and efficiently with Indigenous citizens and Indigenous governments. Courses are delivered online.

Learners will acquire the skills necessary for effective and responsible management and will broaden their understanding of the administrative process. Online program delivery will take into account multiple learning styles and circumstances and may include online lectures, guest speakers, and readings available through texts and online library articles. Instructors will encourage peer support and cross learning.

BED-EDIL.description:
This degree program is offered by the Department of Indigenous Education in the Faculty of Education. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

The Bachelor of Education in Indigenous Language Revitalization offered through the Department of Indigenous Education is a community-based, cohort-driven program that is designed for BC Indigenous community members who want to learn their language and become teachers of their language. The Bachelor of Education in Indigenous Language Revitalization is targeted towards those who want to become professional K-12 teachers in hopes of teaching in either a First Nations administrated or public school. Students will continue building their language capacity to ensure they are qualified to teach in an immersion context if desirable. Students enter this program after completing a Diploma in Indigenous Language Revitalization or equivalent coursework approved by the Chair of Indigenous Education.

Program notes

  • For students who have already successfully completed a college or university course in an Indigenous language and/or are fluent speakers of an Indigenous language, consult with the Academic Adviser of the CILR program to transfer the credit or challenge this elective course requirement.
  • For students who choose LING 185, LING or IED 158, 258, 358, 458, please consult program staff for procedures and requirements of these practicum courses. Also, please refer to Guidelines for Ethical Conduct and Regulations Concerning Practica.
Indigenous language requirement

Students must complete at least one course offered under LING or IED 158, 159, 258, 259, 358, 359, 458, or 459, or take a course in an Indigenous language at a college or university for transfer credit, in order to strengthen knowledge of processes associated with learning an Indigenous language.

For students who have already successfully completed a college or university course in an Indigenous language and/or are fluent speakers of an Indigenous language, consult with the Academic Adviser of the CILR program to transfer the credit or challenge this elective course requirement.

For more information, please contact:
Certificate Program in Indigenous Language Revitalization
Cultural Management Programs
Division of Continuing Studies
University of Victoria
PO Box 3030 STN CSC
Victoria, BC V8W 3N4
Email: cilr@uvic.ca
Phone: 250-721-8457
Fax: 250-721-8774
Website: continuingstudies.uvic.ca/cilr

Indigenous language course challenge

The course challenge process is intended to allow you to receive up to 3 units of elective credit, based on your proficiency in an Indigenous language. If that proficiency has been gained through the completion of coursework at a local college or university, you can apply to transfer that credit to the University of Victoria. However, if your proficiency has been gained through life experience, you can apply to challenge LING 159 or IED 159 and/or LING 259 or IED 259 as described below.

To challenge a course, you are required to provide a letter from a local language authority certifying that you have achieved a degree of proficiency in that language. As well, you will be required to complete a course challenge application form and to submit a fee equivalent to 50% of the tuition assessed for a 1.5 unit course. Based on this application, the academic advisers to the Certificate in Indigenous Language Revitalization will determine if the course challenge is successful, establish the equivalency to LING 159 or IED 159 and/or LING 259 or IED 259 and arrange for the credit to be entered on your academic record.

Please have your language authority complete and sign the LING 159 or IED 159 and/or LING 259 or IED 259 challenge form and return it to us with the course challenge application and fee.

You are urged to complete the course challenge process upon admission to the Certificate Program so that you can plan your elective requirements accordingly.

Please mail your course challenge materials to:

Academic Adviser
Indigenous Language Revitalization Programs
Department of Linguistics
University of Victoria
PO Box 1700
Victoria, BC V8W 2Y2

DIPL-ISP.description:
This 15-unit interdisciplinary program is for students and professionals who want to develop their intercultural knowledge and skills.

Students will develop skills to support all aspects of cultural diversity, inclusion and social change in their community, their workplace and around the world. The program aims to develop students' social responsibility and a clearer understanding of the complex issues at play in a multicultural society.

This interdisciplinary program engages students in a wide range of current issues, including cross-cultural relations, intercultural communication, cultural diversity, and issues of power, oppression and privilege. The program welcomes students from varied backgrounds including those currently involved in professional and volunteer roles in multicultural and cross-cultural settings, as well as participants who would simply like to increase their knowledge and understanding of current social and culturally related issues. The Diploma in Intercultural Studies and Practice may be taken as a stand-alone credential, or concurrently with a Certificate, Diploma or Degree program.Students are responsible for ensuring their course selection conforms to the requirements of their degree program. Students seeking academic advice regarding degree programs should consult the appropriate academic advising centre:

  • Advising Centre, Faculties of Humanities, Science and Social Sciences, A205, University Centre. Telephone: 250-721-7567
  • Advising Centre, Faculty of Education, Room 250, MacLaurin Building. Telephone: 250-721-7877
  • Students in the Faculty of Fine Arts or the Faculty of Human and Social Development should contact the specific department or school.

BSC-KNSM.description:
This degree program is offered by the School of Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education in the Faculty of Education. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

The School of Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education offers a Bachelor of Science Kinesiology degree, which includes the option of studying under a co-operative education model. An Honours degree is also available to those students seeking research experience. The BSc, Kinesiology program requires a degree of specialization in the last two years of study. This degree may permit students to proceed to a professional position in the various fields associated with Kinesiology, or to proceed towards graduate studies, or professional studies (including, but not limited to physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathology, chiropractic, medicine, recreation therapy and teacher education).

Students should note that many of the required Math and Physics courses in the Kinesiology degree have secondary school prerequisites. Anatomy and Physiology 12, Physics 12, Pre-Calculus 12 and Chemistry 12 are recommended and best prepare students to succeed in the Kinesiology program. Anatomy and Physiology 12 and Pre-Calculus 12 and one of Physics or Chemistry 12 are Year 1 (i.e. directly from high school) Admission Requirements. However, students who do not have grade 12 level in the math and sciences can take additional courses at UVic or another institution in order to meet Year 2 Admission requirements and to fulfill their Kinesiology degree requirements. Details of the secondary school prerequisite requirements for Math and Physics courses in the Kinesiology degree are provided in the associated University Calendar course descriptions, and for key courses, on the School’s website as part of notes associated with the description of the recommended sequence in Kinesiology.

The School of Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education accepts approximately 60 students each year (total from both entries: to Year 1 and Year 2) into the BSc Kinesiology program. Entry to year 1 is limited to secondary-school applicants. Applicants with credit from a post-secondary institution must apply for year 2 entry.

specializations.description: The Concentration provides students opportunity to take more courses in environmental law and sustainability.
specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

Students accepted into the Concentration must fulfill requirements of the Concentration and also requirements of the JD Program or the JD/JID Program. Students must obtain a grade of C+ or better in all required and elective courses for the Concentration. Students who successfully complete the Concentration requirements will receive a notation on their transcripts.
specializations.title: Concentration in Environmental Law and Sustainability
specializations.admissionRequirements:
Admission requirements

The Concentration is open to all UVic JD students and JD/JID students who have obtained an average of C+ or better in their previous year of legal studies. Students must apply for admission to the Concentration. See the Associate Dean’s website for details.

JD-LAW.notes:
Part-time students must complete the remainder of the compulsory first-year program in the second academic year of attendance.

Second- and third-year programs

The Faculty of Law may designate courses as compulsory, prerequisite or recommended courses.

In each of the second and third years of the program, a student will enrol in a course program which has been approved by the Dean or the Dean’s nominee.

  • An approved program for a full-time student is one in which a student is enrolled in courses totalling not fewer than 14.5 units and not more than 16.5 units over the academic session (that is, during the 30-week period).
  • An approved program for a part-time student is one in which a student is enrolled in courses totalling not fewer than 7 units and not more than 14.5 units, over the academic session (that is, during the 30-week period).

Without the permission of the Dean or the Dean’s nominee, a full-time student may not carry fewer than 7 units or more than 8.5 units in one term per session (that is, during the 15-week period). Without the permission of the Dean or the Dean’s nominee, a part-time student may not carry fewer than 3 units or more than 7 units in one term per session (that is, during the 15-week period).

In order to complete the program requirements, a student must enrol in approved programs for the second and third years which amount to a total of not fewer than 29 units.

  • An approved program for a full-time student is one in which a student is enrolled in courses totalling not fewer than 14.5 units and not more than 16.5 units over the academic session (that is, during the 30-week period).
  • An approved program for a part-time student is one in which a student is enrolled in courses totalling not fewer than 7 units and not more than 14.5 units, over the academic session (that is, during the 30- week period).

Without the permission of the Dean or the Dean's nominee, a full-time student may not carry fewer than 7 units or more than 8.5 units in one term per session (that is, during the 15-week period). Without the permission of the Dean or the Dean's nominee, a part-time student may not carry fewer than 3 units or more than 7 units in one term per session that is, during the 15-week period).

In order to complete the program requirements, a student must enrol in approved programs for the second, third and fourth years which amount to a total of not fewer than 43.5 units.

Provides a foundation for students interested in pursuing graduate degrees in speech pathology and audiology.

BA-LIAM.notes:
Program notes

  • LING 450 and LING 461 can satisfy more than one requirement if repeated for credit.
  • LING 450 and LING 462 can be used to satisfy the Indigenous Language Structure only if taken in an Indigenous language.

Concentrations

The Department of Linguistics offers concentrations in the BA in Linguistics in the following areas: Language and Society; Language and Speech; Indigenous Languages. The concentrations involve courses that are project-based and provide opportunities for experiential learning. Students complete the required courses noted below within the Major program requirements in Third and Fourth Years.

DIPL-LGM.description:
This program is offered by the School of Public Administration in the Faculty of Human and Social Development. Prospective and current students should consult the School's admission and program requirements.

Students employed or seeking employment in local governments may opt to enrol in the Diploma in Local Government Management. This is a part-time, online program of studies leading to the Diploma in Local Government Management and is offered via distance education. The program is intended for practicing or prospective managers in local government who wish to acquire the skills and background necessary for effective and responsible management, and who are interested in broadening their understanding of the administrative process.

The Diploma will be awarded upon successful completion of 10 courses or 15 units, with an overall GPA of at least 2.0. Courses in this program are applicable towards professional certificates awarded by the Board of Examiners of the British Columbia Ministry responsible for local government (see Local Government Option).
DIPL-LGM.subject: ADMN
DIPL-LGM.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ADMN312 - Leading and Managing in Public and Non-Profit Sectors (1.5)
      • ADMN420 - The Public Policy Process (1.5)
      • ADMN423 - Local Government and Governance (1.5)
      • ADMN445 - Urban and Regional Development (1.5)
      • ADMN452 - Local Government Law (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ADMN330 - Indigenous Governance in Canada (1.5)
      • ADMN331 - Governance for Planetary Health (1.5)
    • If students take both ADMN 330 and 331, one will count towards elective requirements.
    • Complete 6.0 units of:
      other ADMN courses from any of the three areas below.

Social/applied sciences

  • Select from:
    • ADMN314 - Public Sector Research and Analysis (1.5)

Managerial theory and practice

  • Select from:
    • ADMN316 - Public Sector Communications (1.5)
    • ADMN407 - Managing Service Delivery (1.5)
    • ADMN409 - Non-profit Governance and Management (1.5)
    • ADMN411 - Public Sector Project Management (1.5)
    • ADMN421 - Financial Management (1.5)
    • ADMN422 - Ethical Public Management (1.5)
    • ADMN431A - Public Sector Human Resource Management (1.5)
    • ADMN431B - Labour Relations Negotiations (1.5)
    • ADMN437 - Foundations for Program Evaluation (1.5)
    • ADMN477 - Strategic Planning and Implementation (1.5)

Policy areas

  • Select from:
    • ADMN310 - Public Sector Economics (1.5)
    • ADMN311 - Introduction to Public Administration (1.5)
    • ADMN446 - Local Government Land Use Planning (1.5)
    • ADMN462 - Intergovernmental Relations in Canada (1.5)
    • ADMN470 - Contemporary Topics in Administration (1.5 - 3)
    • ADMN490 - Directed Studies (1.5)

  • Students in the Diploma program may select one or more electives from the school's Indigenous Community Development and Governance (ICDG) course offerings, with permission of the school.

ADMN 422 is also required for the Certificate in Local Government Executive Management.

BENG-MECH.description:
This degree program is offered by the Department of Mechanical Engineering in the Faculty of Engineering and Computer Science. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

This program is accredited by the Accreditation Board of Engineers Canada. Accreditation ensures that graduates of the program satisfy the academic requirements for licensure as a professional engineer by Engineers and Geoscientists BC.

Graduate programs

Please refer to the UVic Graduate Calendar for information on studies leading to the MEng, MASc and PhD degrees.
BENG-MECH.subject: MECH
BENG-MECH.requirements:
Year 1

CERT-MDIA.description: This program offers undergraduates a credential in media literacy to expand their career options and enrich their studies in any discipline. Courses focus on experiential learning and the people skills of media practice; critical thinking, communication, and complex problem solving across audio, images, video and text.

CERT-MDIA.notes: No more than 4.5 units (excluding MDIA courses) may be taken in a single department or program.

BA-MDAM.description: This degree program is offered by the Medieval Studies Program in the Faculty of Humanities. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BA-MDAM.subject: MEDI
BA-MDAM.requirements:
Program requirements

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • MEDI303 - The Medieval World (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units from:
      • MEDI360 - Selected Topics in Medieval Culture (1.5)
      • MEDI320 - Topics in Medieval Voices (1.5)
      • MEDI330 - Topics in Medievalism (1.5)
      • MEDI420 - Topics in Medieval Objects (1.5)
      • MEDI430 - Topics in Medieval Places and Spaces (1.5)
      • MEDI440 - Topics in Medieval Intellectual Traditions (1.5)
      • MEDI445 - Topics in Medieval Media (1.5)
    • Complete 9 units of:
      MEDI 300- or 400-level, or courses chosen from the list of Eligible Courses (below). No more than 3.0 units may be selected from any one department.
BA-MDAM.notes:
Program notes

  • The Program strongly recommends that students undertaking a Major in Medieval Studies achieve a reading knowledge of a second language. Introductory courses in Latin (LATI 101 and 102) and Greek (GREE 101 and 102) are particularly recommended for the study of Medieval culture.
  • HSTR 236 (Medieval Europe), or HSTR 236A (The Creation of the Medieval World) and HSTR 236B (The European Middle Age) are suggested as electives.
Double Major

Student pursuing a Double Major may select courses on the Eligible Courses list from their second field of concentration, but the same units cannot be used for both Majors.

BA-MDAH.description: This degree program is offered by the Medieval Studies Program in the Faculty of Humanities. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BA-MDAH.subject: MEDI
BA-MDAH.requirements:
Program requirements

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • MEDI303 - The Medieval World (1.5)
      • MEDI360 - Selected Topics in Medieval Culture (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units from:
      • MEDI320 - Topics in Medieval Voices (1.5)
      • MEDI330 - Topics in Medievalism (1.5)
      • MEDI420 - Topics in Medieval Objects (1.5)
      • MEDI430 - Topics in Medieval Places and Spaces (1.5)
      • MEDI440 - Topics in Medieval Intellectual Traditions (1.5)
      • MEDI445 - Topics in Medieval Media (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • MEDI499 - Honours Graduating Essay (1.5)
    • Complete 15 units of:
      MEDI 300- or 400-level, or courses chosen from the list of Eligible Courses (below). No more than 4.5 units may be selected from any one department.
BA-MDAH.notes:
Program notes

Language requirement

Students are required to demonstrate a reading knowledge of a language other than English. Latin and Greek are particularly recommended, although students may also choose French, German, Italian, Spanish, Old English, or Old Icelandic. A student may apply to the Program to substitute another language. Students will normally fulfill this requirement by completing successfully 3.0 units of 200-level language courses with a grade of C or higher in each course. This requirement may also be fulfilled by completing successfully FRAN 180, or GREE 101 and 102, or LATI 101 and 102, with a grade of C or higher in each course. In special circumstances, students already fluent in a language may request a translation examination administered by the Program.

      • MICR405 - Biotechnology and Synthetic Biology (1.5)
      • MICR408 - Microbial Pathogenesis (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units from CHEM 400 - 490
    • Complete 6 units of electives
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • CHEM499A - Honours Thesis I (1.5)
        • CHEM499B - Honours Thesis II (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • BCMB499A - Undergraduate Thesis I (1.5)
        • BCMB499B - Undergraduate Thesis II (1.5)
BSC-MCSD.notes:
Program notes

  • Students with Chemistry 11 and Pre-Calculus 12 or equivalents must take CHEM 091 before enrolling in CHEM 102. Students with Chemistry 12 and Pre-Calculus 12 or equivalents should not take CHEM 091.
  • CHEM 231 may be taken in the second term of the first year, and 1.5 units of these electives postponed until a later year.
  • BIOL 225 may be taken in the third year as a corequisite to BIOC 300A and 300B. Alternatively, CHEM 245 may be deferred to the fall term of the third year.
  • A list of CHEM 400-level courses and their offering schedule is available on the Department of Chemistry website.
  • An Honours degree will be awarded to students obtaining a graduating GPA of at least 5.5. Students must also achieve a minimum grade of B+ in BCMB 499A and 499B should they choose these courses. If a student fails to meet the standards for the Honours degree, but does meet the Major degree requirements, the departments may consider the appropriate class of Major degree.

MNR-MUST.notes:
Program notes

  • None of the 300-400 level courses taken for the Minor in Museum Studies can be used to complete requirements for a student's Honours, Major, or General Program.
  • Courses may not be used more than once towards the Museum Studies Minor unless the course description indicates that it may be repeated for credit.
  • A student may also complete a General Program that combines a Minor in Museum Studies with one of the General Programs in the Faculty of Humanities or Social Sciences. The degree will be a BA awarded by the faculty offering the General Program.

BA-PHAM.description:
The Physical and Health Education program is intended for people who wish to become a secondary school physical education teacher. Students who wish to become a secondary school physical education teacher complete the Physical and Health Education program and apply for admission to the Diploma in Secondary Teacher Education. Students are not admitted directly into the Physical and Health Education program. Students must first be admitted to the Recreation and Health Education program. After completing year one of the Recreation and Health Education program students may transfer into the Physical and Health Education program. The Physical and Health Education program and the Recreation and Health Education program share a common first year.

The Physical and Health Education program includes all of the courses needed to qualify for the physical and health education teachable subject area as part of an application for admission to the Diploma in Secondary Teacher Education.

BA-PHAM.notes:
*Electives: It is strongly recommended that students who wish to become a secondary school physical education teacher qualify in two teachable subject areas. Students in the Physical and Health Education program should use their electives to meet the requirements of their preferred second teaching area. There are 22.5 units of electives that are available to be used to meet the requirements of a second teaching area. The number of units required in a teachable subject area varies depending on the teaching area that is selected. Students must fulfill all 22.5 units of electives in the Physical and Health Education program, even if their selected second teaching area includes less than 22.5 units. If a student’s selected second teaching area includes more than 22.5 units, the additional units will be taken as surplus to the student’s degree requirements.

**Students must complete a minimum of 3 units of activity courses in addition to the compulsory course EPHE 439 (1.5 units). Students are encouraged to take a diverse range of activity courses, however, EPHE 487 (1.5 units) can be used in place of three, 0.5 unit activity courses. Students may take additional units of activity courses.

MNR-PE.description:
This program is offered by the School of Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education in the Faculty of Education. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

The School of Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education offers a 15.0 unit Minor in Physical Education. The program allows the Physical Education teachable area to be acknowledged as a minor within an undergraduate degree providing students outside of the School of EPHE the option to apply for the Post-Degree Professional Program (PDPP).
MNR-PE.subject: EPHE
MNR-PE.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete 9 units from:
      • EPHE201 - Qualitative Analysis of Human Movement (1.5)
      • EPHE245 - Motor Learning (1.5)
      • EPHE246 - Strategies for Active Health (1.5)
      • EPHE352 - Introduction to Physical Activity Instructional Techniques (1.5)
      • EPHE452 - Strategies for Games in Physical Education (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units from:
      • EPHE346 - Motor Development and Physical Maturation (1.5)
      • EPHE350 - Children and Youth with Special Needs in Physical Activities (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units from:
      • EPHE260 - Exercise Prescription (1.5)
      • EPHE345 - Health Education for Children and Youth (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units from:
      • EPHE104 - Special Activity (0.5)
      • EPHE105 - Swimming (0.5)
      • EPHE106 - Track and Field (0.5)
      • EPHE107 - Gymnastics (0.5)
      • EPHE109 - Dance (0.5)
      • EPHE113 - Golf (0.5)
      • EPHE116 - Badminton (0.5)
      • EPHE117 - Tennis (0.5)
      • EPHE120 - Basketball (0.5)
      • EPHE121 - Soccer (0.5)
      • EPHE122 - Volleyball (0.5)
      • EPHE123 - Rugby (0.5)
      • EPHE124 - Field Hockey (0.5)
      • EPHE126 - Orienteering (0.5)
      • EPHE133 - Strength Training (0.5)
      • EPHE134 - Iyengar Yoga (0.5)
      • EPHE137 - Experiential Outdoor Education (0.5)
      • EPHE439 - Study of Gymnastics (1.5)
      • EPHE487 - Special Topics in Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education (1.5 - 3)

Note

  • EPHE 487 can be taken more than once in different topics and can be in any sport area, with the condition that it includes a significant experiential component related to the sport area and that the course connects to core coursework covered in the Minor in Physical Education or the Physical Education teachable area.
MNR-PE.notes:
Program notes

  • The necessary prerequisites are required for all courses.
  • The Minor in Physical Education is primarily intended for students who want to become secondary school physical education teachers.
  • The number of students able to add the Minor in Physical Education may be limited by the School of Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education based on the availability of spaces in courses associated with the minor.
  • The Minor in Physical Education can only be added to a student's program (i.e., both in-progress and declared) by a Faculty of Education advisor approved by the School of Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education.
  • The School of Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education will not consider granting overrides to register in courses that are required in the Minor in Physical Education until the minor has been declared in a student's degree program.

BSC-GOSD.description:
This single degree program is composed of a selected combination of courses from the Department of Geography and the School of Earth and Ocean Sciences. Students may complete this program in either the Faculty of Social Sciences or the Faculty of Science. Those choosing a Social Sciences degree should consult the Social Sciences Faculty Program Requirements; those choosing a Science degree should must consult the Science Faculty Program Requirements.

Professional registration

With appropriate course selection, this program is intended to fulfill the Geoscientists Canada Knowledge Requirements for the Environmental Geoscience stream, which contribute the academic requirements for registration as a Professional Geoscientist (P.Geo.) through Engineers and Geoscientists British Columbia (EGBC). Students may contact either the School of Earth and Ocean Sciences or EGBC for a current list of course equivalents. EGBC academic requirements may be subject to change. EGBC has additional requirements for registration beyond academic requirements.
BSC-GOSD.subject: EOS
BSC-GOSD.requirements:

    • Complete all of:

      • GEOG104 - Our Digital Earth (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:

    • Complete 1 of the following

      • Complete all of:

      • GEOG418 - Advanced Spatial Analysis and Geo-statistics (1.5)

  • Students who already have credit for an introductory Statistics course numbered 200 or above from another academic unit must consult with a Geography or SEOS Undergraduate advisor before registering in any of GEOG 226, STAT 255, 260. See "Credit Limit - Beginning Level Statistics Courses" in the Course Credit calendar section.
  • EOS 403, 408, 416, 420, 423, 425, 427, 431, 433, 440 and 450 are normally offered in alternate years. Students are advised to consult with the School of Earth and Ocean Sciences to determine when these courses are offered.

MNR-PHYX.description:
This program is offered by the Department of Physics and Astronomy in the Faculty of Science. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

Students should also refer to the Physics and Astronomy Requirements.
MNR-PHYX.subject: PHYS
MNR-PHYX.requirements:
Minimum course requirements

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS120 - Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS130 - Physics II (1.5)
      • Complete all of:
        • PHYS110 - Introductory Physics I (1.5)
        • PHYS111 - Introductory Physics II (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units from PHYS 200 - 499
    • Complete 4.5 units from PHYS 300 - 499
MNR-PHYX.notes:
Program notes

  • The 9.0 units numbered 200 or higher cannot also be used to fulfill the requirements of a student's Honours, Major or General program, or Option. Any course disqualified from the Minor Program by overlap with the requirements of the Honours or Major or General or Option Program may be replaced by another PHYS course at the same level or higher.
  • Students should note that most PHYS courses have MATH pre- and co-requisites. Students who believe that they are appropriately prepared for a PHYS course without having completed the listed prerequisites, such as 3rd or 4th year BEng students who have completed MATH 204, may apply to the department for permission to take it.
  • The combination PHYS 215, 317, 321A, 323, 325, 328 is recommended for students in Electrical Engineering.
  • The combination PHYS 215, 321A, 323, 325, 326, 328 is recommended for students in Mechanical Engineering.

BA-POAH.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Political Science in the Faculty of Social Sciences. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BA-POAH.subject: POLI
BA-POAH.requirements:
Years 1 and 2

  • Complete all of the following
    • Earned a minimum grade of C+ in 1 of:
      • POLI101 - Canadian Politics (1.5)
      • POLI201 - Canadian Institutions of Government (1.5)
    • Earned a minimum grade of C+ in 4 of:
      • POLI101 - Canadian Politics (1.5)
      • POLI103 - The Worlds of Politics (1.5)
      • POLI201 - Canadian Institutions of Government (1.5)
      • POLI202 - An Introduction to Political Theory (1.5)
      • POLI210 - Comparative Politics (1.5)
      • POLI211 - European Integration and the European Union (1.5)
      • POLI217 - Global Development (1.5)
      • POLI240 - International Politics (1.5)
      • POLI263 - The Politics of Indigenous Peoples (1.5)
    • Complete 22.5 units of electives
    • Complete 1.5 units from:
      • POLI263 - The Politics of Indigenous Peoples (1.5)
      • POLI363 - Indigenous Politics in Canada (1.5)

Note

  • A GPA of 6.0 is required in at least 7.5 units of Political Science courses numbered at the 100 or 200 level.
  • It is strongly recommended that students take a broad range of Political Science courses, including at least one on Canadian politics, one on comparative politics, one on international politics, and one in political theory (see below). Some courses on offer will incorporate material from more than one of these fields.

Years 3 and 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of:
      • POLI300A - Ancient and Medieval Political Thought (1.5)
      • POLI300B - Early Modern Political Thought (1.5)
      • POLI300C - Post-Enlightenment Political Thought (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • POLI321 - Introduction to Research Methods in Politics (1.5)
      • POLI338 - Approaches to Political Analysis (Seminar Course) (1.5)
    • Earn a minimum grade of B in each of the following:
      • POLI499 - Honours Seminar and Essay (3.0)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Group II Comparative Politics (see below)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Group III Canadian Politics (see below)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Group IV International Politics (see below)
    • Complete 9.0 units of:
      POLI courses at the 300- or 400-level
    • Complete 9 units of electives

Notes

  • To continue in the program in the fourth year, students must secure a GPA of at least 6.5 in Political Science courses taken during the third year, and maintain an overall sessional GPA of 6.0.
  • POLI 321 and 338 normally are taken in the student’s third year, and 499 in the fourth year.
  • Students must include 1.5 units of 400-level POLI coursework in addition to POLI 499.
  • CE 300 and EUS 300 are each accepted in lieu of 1.5 units of upper-level POLI coursework.

specializations.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Earn a minimum grade of B in each of the following:
      • POLI211 - European Integration and the European Union (1.5)
      • POLI311 - Governments and Politics in Europe (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units of:
      POLI 300A, 300B, 300C, 340, 379, 414. With permission of the department, POLI 319, 349, 433 may be counted if they cover approved European topics.
    • Complete 3 units of:
      300- or 400-level courses on European History or Culture. These courses must be approved by the department.
    • Complete 3 units of:
      Additional courses on European History or Culture. These courses may be at any level and must be approved by the department.
    • Complete 6 units of:
      Modern European Languages.
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • EUS390A - Directed Studies in Europe I (1.5)
      • Complete 1.5 units of:
        Transferrable units from a European university obtained through a UVic International Exchange Program.
      • Complete 1.5 units of:
        Transferrable units from a European university through a Letter of Permission.
      • A minimum of one Co-op work term in a European country through the Social Sciences Co-operative Education program.
specializations.concentrationProgramNotes:
Program notes

  • Students must complete at least 1.5 units of EUS coursework.
specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

The Department of Political Science offers an interdisciplinary option in European Studies for Major and Honours students in Political Science. The option provides students with a specialized training in European politics, history, culture and languages as well as an educational or work experience in a European country. Students wishing to concentrate in European Studies must plan their program in consultation with the Director of European Studies.

Major and Honours students in Political Science who wish to graduate with an option in European Studies must complete:
specializations.title: European Studies Option

BA-POAH.notes:
Program notes

  • Students should complete the 200-level POLI course in a particular field before attempting any 300-level courses in the same field.
  • All 400-level POLI courses are seminar courses open only to students registered in the Political Science Honours or Major program. Other students who wish to register in these courses require permission of the department.
  • POLI 263 can be used to satisfy the Indigenous politics requirement and also count towards lower level requirements.
  • POLI 363 cannot be used to satisfy both the Indigenous politics requirement and the Canadian group requirement.
  • Students must choose 6 units from one of the Groups I-IV (see below) or from an area of specialized concentration approved by the Honours Adviser and the student's supervisor.
  • Honours students should consult with the Adviser when planning their programs for the third and fourth years.

BA-POAM.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Political Science in the Faculty of Social Sciences. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BA-POAM.subject: POLI
BA-POAM.requirements:
Years 1 and 2

  • Complete all of the following
    • Earned a minimum grade of C+ in 1 of:
      • POLI101 - Canadian Politics (1.5)
      • POLI201 - Canadian Institutions of Government (1.5)
    • Earned a minimum grade of C+ in 4 of:
      • POLI101 - Canadian Politics (1.5)
      • POLI103 - The Worlds of Politics (1.5)
      • POLI201 - Canadian Institutions of Government (1.5)
      • POLI202 - An Introduction to Political Theory (1.5)
      • POLI210 - Comparative Politics (1.5)
      • POLI211 - European Integration and the European Union (1.5)
      • POLI217 - Global Development (1.5)
      • POLI240 - International Politics (1.5)
      • POLI263 - The Politics of Indigenous Peoples (1.5)
    • Complete 21.0 units of electives
    • Complete 1.5 units from:
      • POLI263 - The Politics of Indigenous Peoples (1.5)
      • POLI363 - Indigenous Politics in Canada (1.5)

Note

  • It is strongly recommended that students take a broad range of Political Science courses, including at least one on Canadian politics, one on comparative politics, one on international politics, and one in political theory (see below). Some courses on offer will incorporate material from more than one of these fields.

Years 3 and 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of:
      • POLI300A - Ancient and Medieval Political Thought (1.5)
      • POLI300B - Early Modern Political Thought (1.5)
      • POLI300C - Post-Enlightenment Political Thought (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Group II Comparative Politics (see below)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Group III Canadian Politics (see below)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Group IV International Politics (see below)
    • Complete 9.0 units of:
      POLI courses at the 300- or 400-level
    • Complete 15 units of electives

Notes

  • A course on methods of political analysis (POLI 321) is strongly recommended.
  • CE 300 and EUS 300 are each accepted in lieu of 1.5 units of upper-level POLI coursework.
  • Students must include 1.5 units of 400-level POLI coursework in the Major program.

specializations.concentrationProgramNotes:
Program notes

  • Students must complete at least 1.5 units of EUS coursework.
specializations.programRequirements:
Program requirements

The Department of Political Science offers an interdisciplinary option in European Studies for Major and Honours students in Political Science. The option provides students with a specialized training in European politics, history, culture and languages as well as an educational or work experience in a European country. Students wishing to concentrate in European Studies must plan their program in consultation with the Director of European Studies.

Major and Honours students in Political Science who wish to graduate with an option in European Studies must complete:
specializations.title: European Studies Option

BED-ELEP.description:
This degree program is offered by the Department of Curriculum and Instruction in the Faculty of Education. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

This second degree program provides course work and practicum experience designed to produce a well-qualified elementary school teacher. The program has been designed as a co-ordinated, sequenced balance of course work and integrated school observational and practica experiences. In addition to school visits, there is a six-week practicum at the end of the first year and a final practicum in the final term.

This full-time program is designed to be taken over four terms. Normally this takes place over 16 months.

Students are eligible for a BC teaching certificate and the Bachelor of Education (BEd) degree upon successful completion of this program.

Off-campus program

East Kootenay Teacher Education programs

Subject to enrolment, the Bachelor of Education Post-Degree Professional Program (Elementary) is also offered at the College of the Rockies in Cranbrook, BC.

The off-campus program is offered on a part-time basis and typically takes two to three years to complete.

Students interested in the East Kootenay Teacher Education Program should contact an academic adviser in the Faculty of Education for more information.

BED-IEEP.description:
This degree program is offered by the Department of Indigenous Education in the Faculty of Education. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

The Post-Degree Professional Program (Indigenous Education - Elementary) (Bachelor of Education) is composed of 30.0 units normally taken over 6 terms or 24 months. The program promotes relational accountabilities with local First Nations peoples and communities; ensuring students are offered opportunities to learn about local cultural places of significance, local education models; histories and cultures. Courses are designed to support the holistic, reflexive, reflective, experiential and relational growth of learners; as such, courses will be offered on the land, and in the classroom and may also be delivered through intensive experiences. Students will develop a deep understanding of the First Peoples Principles of Learning and meet the qualifications set forth by the Ministry of Education for K-12 teaching. In addition to school visits, there is a six-week practicum a nine-week practicum in the process of qualifying to become an elementary school teacher within the Province of British Columbia through this program.

Students are eligible for a BC teaching certificate and the Bachelor of Education (BEd) degree upon successful completion of this program.

BED-STE*.description:
General information

The Bachelor of Education Post-Degree Professional Program (Secondary), designed for degree holders, provides the education courses needed to obtain a teaching certificate in British Columbia, as well as a Bachelor of Education (BEd).

Students take 30 units of specified courses offered in four terms over a 16-month period. A six-week practicum takes place at the end of the second term and a final practicum takes place in the final term.

All students must be prepared to travel anywhere in British Columbia for the practicum.

Students are eligible for both a BC teaching certificate and the Bachelor of Education (BEd) upon satisfactory completion of the program. Satisfactory completion means achieving a grade-point average of at least 3.00 (UVic C+) on the required course work and successful completion of all practica requirements.

Program details

Because of the professional demands of this program, students are not normally permitted to take courses in addition to those specified. Usually all specified course work must be taken in the order assigned and within the 16-month time frame. The practicum will be denied or delayed if the requisite course work is not completed to satisfactory standard.

Undergraduate course availability

BA-PH.description:
This degree program is offered by the School of Public Health and Social Policy in the Faculty of Human and Social Development. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

The Bachelor of Arts in Public Health is a four year degree program consisting of 30 units of core coursework. Within the program, students select one of four applied areas of focus: Disability Studies; Indigenous Peoples’ Health; International and Global Health Development; Ageing.

The BA in Public Health is offered using a blended learning approach. All courses are offered by distance education using online learning technologies. All students are required to attend two onsite components at UVic: the first provides an introduction to the program, and learning strategies (online learning). The second is a conferencing opportunity where undergraduate, as well as graduate students, present their final papers/projects (HLTH 435). Some students will also require a third onsite course depending on the area of focus.
BA-PH.subject: HLTH
BA-PH.requirements:
Term 1 (Sep-Dec)

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • HLTH253 - Introduction to Indigenous Health in Canada (1.5)
      • HLTH300 - Social Determinants of Health (1.5)
      • HLTH320 - Health Program Planning and Project Management (1.5)
      • HLTH350 - Health Research Literacy (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      applied area of focus

Note

  • Successful completion of EPHE 351 with a minimum grade of 2.0 (C) prior to admission to the BA in Public Health will be accepted in lieu of HLTH 300.

Term 2 (Jan-Apr)

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • HLTH252 - Principles of Public and Population Health (1.5)
      • HLTH301 - Health Systems in Canada (1.5)
      • HLTH425 - Introductory Statistics (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      applied area of focus

Term 3 (May-Aug)

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • HLTH351 - Practice of Evaluation Research (1.5)
      • HLTH360 - Health Promotion (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      applied area of focus
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      electives that enhance their Bachelor of Public Health course work. The electives can be courses at UVic or transferable to UVic, at the 200 level or above.

Term 4 (Sep-Dec)

  • Complete all of:
    • HLTH401 - Health Policy and Health Governance (1.5)
    • HLTH403 - Community Centred Public Health (1.5)
    • HLTH404 - Inter-Professional Practice (1.5)

Term 5 (Jan-Apr)

  • Complete all of:
    • HLTH430 - Practicum (3.0)
    • HLTH435 - Culminating Major Paper (3.0)

Applied areas of focus

  • Students select one applied area of focus

Ageing

  • Complete all of:
    • AGEI472 - Healthy Ageing (1.5)
    • AGEI473 - Chronic Disease and Ageing (1.5)
    • HLTH405 - Advocacy for Ageing and Disability in Canadian Society (1.5)

Disability Studies

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • DSST440 - Introduction to Disability Studies (1.5)
      • HLTH405 - Advocacy for Ageing and Disability in Canadian Society (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • AGEI472 - Healthy Ageing (1.5)
      • AGEI473 - Chronic Disease and Ageing (1.5)
      • CYC464 - Disability Studies and CYC Praxis (1.5)
      • HLTH402 - Health and Community Supportive Technologies (1.5)
      • INGH452 - Indigenous Understandings of Healing and Wellness (1.5)
      • INGH453 - Wise Practices in Indigenous Community Health (1.5)
      • INTS460 - Foundations in International and Global Health (1.5)
      • INTS462 - The Role of Knowledge in Global Health (1.5)
      • SOCW469 - Redefining Abilities in the Context of Theory and Practice (1.5)
    • Other courses may be selected with permission of the Program Advisor.

Indigenous Peoples’ Health

  • Complete all of:
    • HLTH406 - Indigenous Global Health (1.5)
    • INGH452 - Indigenous Understandings of Healing and Wellness (1.5)
    • INGH453 - Wise Practices in Indigenous Community Health (1.5)

International and Global Health and Human Development

  • Complete all of:
    • HLTH406 - Indigenous Global Health (1.5)
    • INTS460 - Foundations in International and Global Health (1.5)
    • INTS462 - The Role of Knowledge in Global Health (1.5)

DIPL-PSM.description:
This program is offered by the School of Public Administration in the Faculty of Human and Social Development. Prospective and current students should consult the School's admission and program requirements.

The School of Public Administration offers a part-time, off-campus program of studies leading to the Diploma in Public Sector Management, which is available via distance education. The program is intended for practicing or prospective managers in the public and non-profit sectors who wish to acquire the skills and background necessary for effective and responsible management, and who are interested in broadening their understanding of the administrative process.

The Diploma will be awarded upon successful completion of 10 courses or 15.0 units, with an overall GPA of at least 2.0.
DIPL-PSM.subject: ADMN
DIPL-PSM.requirements:
Minimum course requirements

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ADMN310 - Public Sector Economics (1.5)
      • ADMN311 - Introduction to Public Administration (1.5)
      • ADMN312 - Leading and Managing in Public and Non-Profit Sectors (1.5)
      • ADMN420 - The Public Policy Process (1.5)
      • ADMN421 - Financial Management (1.5)
      • ADMN431A - Public Sector Human Resource Management (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ADMN330 - Indigenous Governance in Canada (1.5)
      • ADMN331 - Governance for Planetary Health (1.5)
    • If students take both ADMN 330 and 331, one will count towards elective requirements.
    • Complete 4.5 units from:
      • ADMN314 - Public Sector Research and Analysis (1.5)
      • ADMN316 - Public Sector Communications (1.5)
      • ADMN407 - Managing Service Delivery (1.5)
      • ADMN409 - Non-profit Governance and Management (1.5)
      • ADMN411 - Public Sector Project Management (1.5)
      • ADMN422 - Ethical Public Management (1.5)
      • ADMN423 - Local Government and Governance (1.5)
      • ADMN431B - Labour Relations Negotiations (1.5)
      • ADMN437 - Foundations for Program Evaluation (1.5)
      • ADMN445 - Urban and Regional Development (1.5)
      • ADMN446 - Local Government Land Use Planning (1.5)
      • ADMN452 - Local Government Law (1.5)
      • ADMN462 - Intergovernmental Relations in Canada (1.5)
      • ADMN470 - Contemporary Topics in Administration (1.5 - 3)
      • ADMN477 - Strategic Planning and Implementation (1.5)
      • ADMN490 - Directed Studies (1.5)

  • Students in the Minor in Public Administration program may select one or more electives from the school's Indigenous Community Development and Governance (ICDG) course offerings, with permission of the school.
DIPL-PSM.notes:
Program notes

The Local Government Option has been identified by the Provincial Board of Examiners, in consultation with the Local Government Management Association of BC, as a mandatory educational requirement for the following credentials:

  • Certificate in Local Government Administration
  • Certificate in Local Government Statutory Administration
  • Certificate in Local Government Executive Management

With these courses, in combination with other educational qualifications and relevant work experience in local government in British Columbia, local government employees may apply to the Board of Examiners for certification.

For further certification information contact:
Administrator, Board of Examiners
Ministry of Municipal Affairs and Housing
E-mail: BoardofExaminers@gov.bc.ca

or send a fax to: 250-387-7972
or
Executive Director, Local Government
Management Association of BC
Suite 710A - 880 Douglas Street
Victoria BC V8W 2B7
Phone: 250-383-7032
Email: office@lgma.ca

BA-RHAH.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Exercise Science, Physical and Health Education in the Faculty of Education. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BA-RHAH.subject: ADMN
BA-RHAH.notes:
Program notes

Interfaculty Minor

A student who completes the requirements for the RHED program, and also completes the courses prescribed for one of the academic units listed under the General Program or the courses prescribed in the Calendar for a Minor program offered in another faculty, will receive a Minor in that academic unit. The Minor will be added to the student’s academic record only if the courses taken for the Minor are not part of the core requirements for the RHED program, and only if the student formally declares the Minor program through the EPHE Adviser. Only one Minor may be declared. Students interested in pursuing an Interfaculty Minor should discuss this program with the EPHE Adviser. Note that a Minor in Kinesiology is not available.

BA-RHAM.notes:
*Work term opportunity: Students in the Recreation and Health Education program must complete three work terms. A student may challenge one work term based on previous workplace experience. If a student’s work term challenge is successful, they will be required to only complete two additional work terms. The recommended sequence of required courses identifies four times at which a work term might potentially be undertaken. Students should note that the number of work terms that need to be completed, and when those work terms are undertaken, may influence the sequence in which they complete their required courses.

**Students must complete a minimum of 1.5 units of activity courses. A 1.5 unit activity course can be used in place of three, 0.5 unit activity courses. Students are, however, encouraged to take a diverse range of activity courses. Students may take additional units of activity courses if they wish.

Program notes

  • The Recreation and Health Education program and the Physical and Health Education program share a common first year. Students who wish to become a secondary school physical education teacher will be given the option to transfer into the Physical and Health Education program when they have completed year one of the Recreation and Health Education program. Students in the Physical and Health Education program are not required to complete work terms.
  • Of the 12.0 units of electives, normally 7.5 units must be 300- or 400-level.
