DIPL-SJS.description:
Social Justice Studies is a program that aims to provide students with a thorough understanding of the range of ways to address and engage with issues of social inequity and injustice in the contemporary world from a variety of disciplinary perspectives. A Diploma in Social Justice Studies is offered by the Faculty of Social Sciences in cooperation with the Division of Continuing Studies, while the majority of the program's instructors, students and courses are housed within the Faculties: Social Sciences, Humanities, Human and Social Development, and Education. The Diploma requires an additional 3 units of coursework compared to the SJS Minor. The Diploma in Social Justice Studies requires 15 units of coursework and can be taken as a stand-alone credential, or as a concurrent credential with a Certificate or Degree Program. Students need to apply through Continuing Studies for acceptance into the Diploma Program. Once accepted into the program, students are strongly encouraged to plan their program in consultation with the Director of Social Justice Studies sjs@uvic.ca.

Further information can be found on the Social Justice Studies website. For queries about the Diploma Program, please phone 250-721-7860 or visit the Continuing Studies website.
DIPL-SJS.subject: SJS
DIPL-SJS.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • SJS100 - Introduction to Theories of Social Justice (1.5)
      • SJS200 - Introduction to the Practice of Social Justice (1.5)
      • SJS400A - Seminar in Social Justice Studies (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • SJS400B - Practising Social Justice in the Field (1.5)
      • Complete 1.5 units of:
        Theory and Method courses or Substantive courses.
    • Complete 3 units of:
      Theory and Method courses.
    • Complete 3 units of:
      Substantive courses.
    • Complete 3 units of:
      Theory and Method courses or Substantive courses.
DIPL-SJS.notes:
Program notes

  • No more than 3 units may be taken from any single department, program or school (with the exception of SJS courses).
  • Students cannot complete both a Diploma in SJS and a Minor in SJS.

MNR-SJS.description:
The Faculty of Social Sciences offers an interdisciplinary General and Minor Program in Social Justice Studies while the majority of the program's instructors, students and courses are housed within the following Faculties: Social Sciences, Humanities, Human and Social Development and Education. The program is also available as a Diploma, through the Division of Continuing Studies. The aim of the program is to provide students with a thorough understanding of the range of ways to address and engage with issues of social inequity and injustice in the contemporary world from a variety of disciplinary perspectives.

By completing the requirements for the General Program together with an Honours, Major, or General program, students may obtain a Minor.

Academic advising queries for this program can be directed to the Social Justice Studies Director sjs@uvic.ca.
MNR-SJS.subject: SJS
MNR-SJS.requirements:
• Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • SJS100 - Introduction to Theories of Social Justice (1.5)
      • SJS200 - Introduction to the Practice of Social Justice (1.5)
      • SJS400A - Seminar in Social Justice Studies (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of:
        • SJS400B - Practising Social Justice in the Field (1.5)
      • Complete 1.5 units of:
        Theory and Method courses, or Substantive courses.
    • Complete 3 units of:
      Theory and Method courses.
    • Complete 3 units of:
      Substantive courses.
MNR-SJS.notes:
Program notes

  • Normally, students take SJS 100 first, but SJS 100 and SJS 200 may be taken in either order, or concurrently. SJS 100 and SJS 200 are interdisciplinary team-taught courses.
  • No more than 3 units may be taken from any single department, program or school (with the exception of SJS courses).
  • Only one Minor may be declared on any degree program.
  • No SJS elective course can count as credit towards both the minor and a major.
  • Students cannot complete both a Diploma in SJS and a Minor in SJS.

PSC-SPED.description:
This program is offered by the Department of Educational Psychology and Leadership Studies in the Faculty of Education. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.

The Department of Educational Psychology and Leadership Studies offers a Professional Specialization Certificate (PSC) in Special and Inclusive Education. This 7.5 unit program is designed for teachers who have an undergraduate degree and teacher certification. Normally, students entering the program will also have two years teaching or equivalent experience. As a condition of admission to all Special Education programs, students must undergo a Criminal Record Check in compliance with the BC Criminal Records Review Act. Using a variety of course delivery methods, the Certificate courses are designed and scheduled to be completed part-time. The general foci of the Certificate program are: high and low incidence special needs and their effect on development, learning, and behaviour; legal and ethical issues in the delivery of services to students with special needs; BC Ministry of Education Policies and Procedures; collaboration and consultation in special education; special education assessment (Level B) and identification of learning needs; and individualized education program (IEP) design, delivery, and evaluation.

Program fee

Upon entry, students in the PSC in Special and Inclusive Education pay a non-refundable fee. For more information, please consult the Educational Psychology & Leadership Studies website.
PSC-SPED.subject: ED
PSC-SPED.requirements:
• Complete all of:
    • ED-D405 - Advanced Educational Exceptionality (1.5)
    • ED-D402 - Assessment For Special Education (1.5)
    • ED-D415 - Level B Assessment and Instructional Programming (3.0)
    • ED-D427 - Collaboration and Consultation in Special Education (1.5)
PSC-SPED.notes:
Program notes

  • Students wishing to pursue an M.A. or M.Ed. following completion of the certificate may, subject to approval, apply 1.5 units of their certificate course work toward their graduate degree in Special Education.
  • No transfer credit from outside institutions can be used for credit in the Professional Specialization Certificate in Special and Inclusive Education. ED-D 402, 405 or 415 can be used for credit when taken outside the requirements of a previous degree, certificate or diploma, and completed within 5 years of the date of application to the Certificate program.
  • If a student has completed any of these courses for credit in a previous degree an equivalent substitute course must be approved by the department.​

specializations.programRequirements:
Students may enter the Applied Theatre Focus after completing the first-year Theatre requirements. The Applied Theatre program allies the art of the theatre with effective pedagogy to build upon the growing recognition of theatre as an educative methodology in matters of social, political, economic and therapeutic concerns. The program provides the theoretical and experiential foundations that will serve those who wish to examine the use of theatre forms as they apply to teaching and/or non-theatrical settings, such as cultural, recreation and community centres, historic and environmental sites, museums, prisons, hospitals, social service and health agencies.

Students considering careers in elementary, middle or secondary schools are urged to consult with the Teacher Education Advising Office early to plan their undergraduate programs.

specializations.description:
Students may enter the Directing Focus after completing the second-year Theatre courses required for this focus.

The Directing Focus is a preparatory program only. The foundation of its philosophy is that emerging directors must first secure a strong liberal arts education, as well as experience in all aspects of theatre production, before moving on to an in-depth study of directing. Students seeking entry into this option should secure the advice of the department on all required and elective courses before the end of their first year of the Theatre Program.

BFA-THFM.notes:
Program notes

  • The Fine Arts co-requisite is a Faculty of Fine Arts requirement. Students registered in other faculties or pursuing more than one Fine Arts program should consult academic advising for their faculty.
  • ATWP 135 and an additional 1.5 units of English electives must be taken before 30 units are completed.
  • All courses should be taken in the sequence indicated. Failure to follow the course listings suggested for each year and for each Focus may jeopardize the ability to complete the BFA degree within four years.
  • THEA 120B is strongly recommended for students interested in pursuing the Performance Focus.
  • THEA 132B is strongly recommended for students interested in pursuing the Applied Theatre Focus.
  • The decision to take THEA 120B and THEA 132B may require some students to complete more than 60 units to complete their Focus requirements.

Program notes

BA-THAH.notes:
• The Fine Arts co-requisite is a Faculty of Fine Arts requirement. Students registered in other faculties or pursuing more than one Fine Arts program should consult academic advising for their faculty.
  • A third-year Honours student whose GPA falls below 3.5 in that year, or below 6.0 in designated Theatre History courses, will normally be required to withdraw from the Honours Program.
  • A fourth-year student whose graduating GPA is lower than 3.5, but who otherwise meets the University's requirements for graduation, will receive a BFA in the Theatre History Focus if the BFA requirements have been met.
  • To graduate with a BA Honours in Theatre History, students require a minimum of 30 units of Theatre; at least 18 units must be in designated upper-level Theatre History courses.
  • 6 units of electives must be in approved, related disciplines. Consultation with the BA Honours Advisor will be necessary to determine these courses.

CERT-TCA.description:
This program is offered by the School of Environmental Studies in partnership with the Division of Continuing Studies. It is designed to be accessible to diverse and non-traditional learners, with all required classes available in distance, hybrid (F2F and online) or intensive formats. This is meant to ensure that the Certificate can be completed by working professionals and those living at a distance, as well as current undergraduate students. Requiring a total of seven courses, 10.5 units, it can be completed in a calendar year, combined with other studies, or completed at a slower pace. Courses will integrate academic and practitioner knowledge and experience, including that of Indigenous knowledge holders, to support the development of applied skills for climate action.

In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty adviser for details program and Faculty requirements.
CERT-TCA.subject: TCA
CERT-TCA.requirements:
Minimum course requirements

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • TCA210 - Introduction to the Human Dimensions of Climate Change (1.5)
      • TCA310 - Transformation in Complex Systems (1.5)
      • TCA320 - Politics, Policies and Planning for Climate Action (1.5)
    • Complete 6 units from:
      • ADMN330 - Indigenous Governance in Canada (1.5)
      • ADMN331 - Governance for Planetary Health (1.5)
      • ADMN462 - Intergovernmental Relations in Canada (1.5)
      • ECON383 - Climate Economics (1.5)
      • EOS130 - Climate Change (1.5)
      • EOS365 - Climate and Society (1.5)
      • ES314 - Philosophy and the Environment (1.5)
      • ES365 - Climate and Society (1.5)
      • ES378 - Leadership Skills for Change (1.5)
      • ES405 - Climate, Energy and Politics (1.5)
      • ES411 - Environmental Solutions (1.5)
      • GEOG130 - Climate Change (1.5)
      • GNDR337 - Climate Migration (1.5)
      • PHIL333 - Philosophy and the Environment (1.5)
      • POLI357 - Canadian Environmental Politics (1.5)
      • PSYC326 - The Environmental Psychology of Places and the World (1.5)
      • SOCI437 - Issues in Environmental Sociology and Climate Change (1.5)
      • TCA410 - Indigenous-Led Climate Action (1.5)
      • TCA415 - Adaptation Planning and the Built Environment (1.5)
      • TCA420 - Water Futures: Drought, Fire, Floods, Collaborative Governance (1.5)
      • TCA425 - Organizing for Transformative Change (1.5)
      • TCA430 - Future Ecosystems and Communities (1.5)
      • TCA480 - Special Topics in Transformative Climate Action (1.5)
      • TCA490 - Practicum in Transformative Climate Action (1.5)
CERT-TCA.notes:
• All TCA courses will regularly be offered as asynchronous, online courses and/or in-person intensive courses. Most non-TCA courses will be offered in person over a full term. Students enrolled by distance or joining from off campus may thus want to focus on TCA 410-490 to fulfill the 6 units of required electives.
  • Environmental Studies double major students may apply up to 4.5 units of TCA courses towards their ES major. (ES major students may use up to 4.5 units from the RNS or the TCA program).
  • HDCC courses may be applied to the Certificate until 2028.
  • The 6 units of electives must be at upper year 300/400 level with the exception of GEOG/EOS 130.
  • At least 9 units must be completed at UVic.
  • Students cannot complete both a Certificate in Transformative Climate Action and a Minor or Certificate in HDCC.
  • Queries about the program, its prerequisites, or its list of approved courses should be directed to the Division of Continuing Studies and the TCA Director.

    • Complete 1 of the following

      • An alternate elective course may be determined in consultation with the Cultural Resource Management Program
PSC-VICE.notes:
Program notes

  • Students who complete a Professional Specialization Certificate (PSC) in Visitor and Community Engagement are able to transfer four courses (6.0 units) upon admission to the Diploma in Cultural Resource Management.
  • Courses taken for a PSC or for the diploma cannot be used to complete requirements for a Major, Honours, or Minor in Art History and Visual Studies, or a Minor in Museum Studies. However, they can be used to satisfy co- or pre-requisites.
  • Students may register in two credentials concurrently. Courses from the PSC in Collections Management and/or PSC in Visitor and Community Engagement may be laddered into the diploma to a maximum of 10.5 units combined. For laddering to occur, the PSC must be awarded concurrently with or prior to the diploma.
  • Credit for courses applied to a PSC cannot be applied to an additional certificate program.

      • ART390 - Directed Studies in Visual Arts (1.5 - 4.5)
      • ART395 - Visual Structures in the Imaginative Realm I (6.0)
      • ART490 - Directed Studies (1.5 - 3)
MNR-VART.notes:
Program notes

Please ensure that you have the necessary prerequisites for all classes you plan to take.

Courses taken for the Minor cannot be used to complete requirements for a Major Program. However, they can be used to satisfy co- or prerequisites.

A student may also complete a General Program that combines a Visual Arts Minor with one of the General Programs in Humanities or Social Sciences. The degree will be a BA awarded by the faculty offering the General Program.

BFA-VACS.type: Bachelor of Fine Arts - Combined Major
BFA-VACS.description: The Department of Visual Arts and the Department of Computer Science have designed a program leading to a combined BFA Major Degree. Students intending to pursue this combined program must consult the Undergraduate Adviser in either Fine Arts or Computer Science at the latest after completing all of the first-year requirements.
BFA-VACS.subject: ART
BFA-VACS.requirements:
Year 1

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ART103 - Foundation Drawing and Painting (1.5)
      • ART104 - Foundation Sculpture and Material Methods (1.5)
      • ART105 - Foundation Photography and Video Art (1.5)
      • ART106 - Foundation Core Media Technologies and Arts (1.5)
      • CSC110 - Fundamentals of Programming I (1.5)
      • CSC115 - Fundamentals of Programming II (1.5)
      • MATH122 - Logic and Foundations (1.5)
      • STAT255 - Statistics for Life Sciences I (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • MATH100 - Calculus I (1.5)
      • MATH109 - Introduction to Calculus (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of:
      Electives (students who have not satisfied the Academic Writing Requirement (AWR) should choose 1.5 units from an AWR -satisfying course)

Year 2

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ART150 - Introduction to Contemporary Art Theory, Criticism and Practice (1.5)
      • CSC225 - Algorithms and Data Structures I (1.5)
      • CSC230 - Introduction to Computer Architecture (1.5)
      • MATH211 - Matrix Algebra I (1.5)
      • SENG265 - Software Development Methods (1.5)
    • Complete 6 units from:
      • ART201 - Drawing (1.5)
      • ART202 - Drawing (1.5)
      • ART211 - Painting (1.5)
      • ART212 - Painting (1.5)
      • ART221 - Sculpture (1.5)
      • ART222 - Sculpture (1.5)
      • ART241 - Photography (1.5)
      • ART242 - Photography (1.5)
      • ART261 - Digital Media Arts I (1.5)
      • ART262 - Digital Media Arts II (1.5)
      • ART271 - Video Art (1.5)
      • ART272 - Video Art (1.5)
    • Complete 1.5 units of electives

Year 3

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 6 units from:
      • ART300 - Drawing (3.0)
      • ART306 - Studies in Drawing, Photo, Media and Interdisciplinary Practice (6.0)
      • ART310 - Painting (3.0)
      • ART320 - Sculpture (3.0)
      • ART334 - Multi-Media Printmaking (3.0)
      • ART340 - Photography (3.0)
      • ART351 - Special Studies (1.5 - 3)
      • ART352 - Audain Studio Seminar (1.5 - 3)
      • ART353 - Visiting Artist Talk Series (1.5)
      • ART360 - Extended Media Practices (3.0)
      • ART370 - Video Art (3.0)
      • ART380 - Curatorial Direction (3.0)
      • ART390 - Directed Studies in Visual Arts (1.5 - 4.5)
      • ART395 - Visual Structures in the Imaginative Realm I (6.0)
    • Complete 3 units from:
      • CSC226 - Algorithms and Data Structures II (1.5)
      • CSC320 - Foundations of Computer Science (1.5)
      • CSC360 - Operating Systems (1.5)
      • CSC370 - Database Systems (1.5)
    • Complete all of:
      • SENG310 - Human Computer Interaction (1.5)
    • Complete 4.5 units of electives

Year 4

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete 1 of:
        • ART306 - Studies in Drawing, Photo, Media and Interdisciplinary Practice (6.0)
        • ART395 - Visual Structures in the Imaginative Realm I (6.0)
      • Complete all of the following
        • Complete all of:
          • CSC497 - Interdisciplinary Project (1.5)
        • Complete 4.5 units of:
          ART 300- or 400-level
    • Complete all of:
      • CSC305 - Introduction to Computer Graphics (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units of:
      CSC 400-level (1.5 units may be SENG 400-level)
    • Complete 4.5 units of electives

PSC-VNPM.description: This program is offered by the School of Public Administration in the Faculty of Human and Social Development. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
PSC-VNPM.subject: ADMN
PSC-VNPM.requirements:
Minimum course requirements

  • Complete all of the following
    • Complete all of:
      • ADMN409 - Non-profit Governance and Management (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of:
      • ADMN437 - Foundations for Program Evaluation (1.5)
      • ADMN477 - Strategic Planning and Implementation (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units from:
      • ADMN411 - Public Sector Project Management (1.5)
      • ADMN421 - Financial Management (1.5)
      • ADMN470 - Contemporary Topics in Administration (1.5 - 3)
      • ADMN477 - Strategic Planning and Implementation (1.5)
      • ADMN490 - Directed Studies (1.5)
      • ADMN330 - Indigenous Governance in Canada (1.5)
      • ADMN331 - Governance for Planetary Health (1.5)
      • ADMN437 - Foundations for Program Evaluation (1.5)
      • ADMN431A - Public Sector Human Resource Management (1.5)
      • ADMN312 - Leading and Managing in Public and Non-Profit Sectors (1.5)

Note

  • Complete all of the following
    • ADMN 470 and ADMN 490 may only be used if the topic is relevant to the specialization.
    • If student takes both ADMN 437 and 477, one can be counted as required, the other as an elective.

BA-WRAM.description: This degree program is offered by the Department of Writing in the Faculty of Fine Arts. In addition to the requirements below, students must consult their Faculty program requirements.
BA-WRAM.subject: WRIT
BA-WRAM.requirements:
Minimum course requirements

  • Complete all of the following
    • Earn a minimum grade of B in each of the following:
      • WRIT100 - Introduction to Writing (3.0)
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Select from:
        • AHVS120 - Exploring World Art (1.5)
        • AHVS121 - Understanding Visual Communication (1.5)
        • ART150 - Introduction to Contemporary Art Theory, Criticism and Practice (1.5)
        • ART151 - An Introduction to Contemporary Visual Art (1.5)
        • FA101 - Creative Being (1.5)
        • FA245 - The Arts and Technology I (1.5 - 3)
        • MUS109 - Great Film Music (1.5)
        • MUS116 - Music Appreciation (1.5)
        • THEA102 - Theatre Appreciation from Page to Stage (1.5)
        • THEA111 - Theatre History I (1.5)
      • This list is the Fine Arts co-requisite; this is a Faculty of Fine Arts requirement. See note below.
    • Complete 3 units from:
      • WRIT201A - Introduction to Poetry Workshop (1.5)
      • WRIT202A - Introduction to Fiction Workshop (1.5)
      • WRIT203A - Introduction to Playwriting Workshop (1.5)
      • WRIT204A - Introduction to Creative Nonfiction Workshop (1.5)
      • WRIT218A - Introduction to Screenwriting Workshop (1.5)
    • Complete 3 units from:
      • WRIT201B - Poetry Workshop (1.5)
      • WRIT202B - Fiction Workshop (1.5)
      • WRIT203B - Playwriting Workshop (1.5)
      • WRIT204B - Creative Nonfiction Workshop (1.5)
      • WRIT218B - Screenwriting Workshop (1.5)
    • Complete 1 of the following
        Poetry
      • Complete all of the following
        • Complete 4.5 units from:
          • WRIT303 - Poetry Workshop (1.5)
          • WRIT401 - Advanced Poetry Workshop (1.5)
        • WRIT 303 to be taken twice for a total of 3.0 units.
        • Fiction
      • Complete all of the following
        • Complete 4.5 units from:
          • WRIT304 - Fiction Workshop (1.5)
          • WRIT402 - Advanced Fiction Workshop (1.5)
        • WRIT 304 to be taken twice for a total of 3.0 units.
      • Playwriting
    • Complete 1 of the following
      • Complete all of the following
        • Complete 4.5 units from:
          • WRIT305 - Playwriting Workshop (1.5)
          • WRIT403 - Advanced Playwriting Workshop (1.5)
        • WRIT 305 to be taken twice for a total of 3.0 units.
      • Complete 4.5 units from:
        • WRIT305 - Playwriting Workshop (1.5)
        • WRIT325 - Writing for Theatrical Production Workshop (1.5)
        • WRIT403 - Advanced Playwriting Workshop (1.5)
      • Creative nonfiction
    • Complete all of the following
      • Complete 4.5 units from:
        • WRIT316 - Creative Nonfiction Workshop (1.5)
        • WRIT416 - Advanced Creative Nonfiction Workshop (1.5)
      • WRIT 316 to be taken twice for a total of 3.0 units.
      • Screenwriting
    • Complete 6.0 units from:
      • WRIT318 - Screenwriting Workshop (1.5)
      • WRIT320 - Writing and Film Production Workshop (1.5)
      • WRIT326 - Media Production for Writers (1.5)
      • WRIT418 - Advanced Screenwriting Workshop (1.5)
    • Complete all of the following
      • Complete 9 units of:
        300-400-level WRIT courses.
      • Students that have not completed WRIT 418 are required to complete 10.5 units of 300-400 level WRIT courses.
BA-WRAM.notes:
Program notes

  • The Fine Arts co-requisite is a Faculty of Fine Arts requirement. Students registered in other faculties or pursuing more than one Fine Arts program should consult academic advising for their faculty.
  • Students are advised to work toward a Double Major, since enrolment in workshops is limited, and spaces are not guaranteed. Without a concentration of courses in a separate discipline, students may find themselves delayed in graduating.
  • In addition to the Fine Arts co-requisite, if at least 7.5 units of electives are chosen from courses offered by other departments within the Faculty of Fine Arts, the degree awarded may be either a Bachelor of Fine Arts or Bachelor of Arts; otherwise, the degree awarded will be a Bachelor of Arts.
